The disorder existed before men put a name to it. In the middle of the last century they began to study it. Italian doctors with names like prayers - Bocca, Calearo, Cassinari. They developed their tests and their methods while across the ocean Kimura worked on his own solutions like some medieval alchemist searching for gold in lead. In seventy-seven they gathered, these seekers of truth, to share what little they knew of this thing that lived in the minds of children.

The manifestations came like specters in the night. A man might hear perfectly well yet be unable to tell where the sound originated as if the world itself had become unmoored from direction and space. Words might blur together like watercolors in rain. Patterns of sound that made sense to others became meaningless rhythms without form or substance. The subtle shifts in human speech that carry meaning beyond the words themselves - these too could be lost leaving only hollow shells of communication behind.

They tested for it in sterile rooms with machines that measured the invisible. Audiologists psychologists speech pathologists all with their instruments and questionnaires seeking answers in the darkness of the human mind. No single test could reveal its presence with certainty. Like tracking some mythical beast they followed its spoor through the forest of human consciousness looking for signs and markers that might betray its presence. They presented sounds in pairs and groups watching how the mind failed to separate them like a prospector sifting through river mud for precious metals that might or might not exist.

They were all of them broken things. That's what I'd seen. Souls fractured and scattered like shattered glass on concrete, glinting dangerous in the sun. I knew then what I must do. The path ahead lay clear as bones bleached white in desert sand. Social work. To wade into the darkness where children huddle against walls and families eat themselves alive with poison words and harder things.

The values rode with me like old companions. Service. Respect. Ethics raw and pure as winter wind. Commitment to mend what's torn between people and to keep my own blade sharp for the work ahead. These weren't just words written in some college manual. They were blood truth.

I wandered long years uncertain, watching folks try to outrun their demons. Some found the bottle. Others found worse things. I studied psychology then, trying to understand the machinery of hurt. But understanding ain't enough. Never was.

The boy came in summer. Sixteen and scared, perched on my friend's couch like a wounded bird. His parents had done things. Bad things. Dark things that leave marks deeper than skin. I went to their house next day after he called the law. Told the police my credentials, such as they were. They let me talk to the parents. Watched them squirm and lie, calling their boy manipulative, calling violence simple disputes. That's when I knew. Knew what I had to become.

Justice is a strange thing in this world. We talk about individuals like they're precious gold but try to stamp them all the same shape. I never did take to that. Colored my hair wild as desert flowers, marked my flesh with metal, stood with the outcasts and the different ones. Fought against the darkness of racism and hate wherever it showed its teeth. Some folks call that rebellion. I call it truth.

The road ahead is dark and full of thorns, but I'll walk it anyway. Because somewhere out there children are crying in the night, and somebody's got to answer.

Sleep and its disorders lay before us like ancient riddles writ in the flesh of man. They come in forms both primary and secondary, though such distinctions matter little to those who walk the midnight hours seeking rest that will not come. There are those who study these afflictions, cataloging them in neat rows like bones in an archaeologist's tent, sorting them into categories they call Dyssomnias and Parasomnias, words that taste of dust and academia.

The sleepless ones. They carry their burden like a cross, dragging it through days that blur into nights that refuse to yield their peace. Primary Insomnia they call it, when sleep becomes a stranger for thirty nights or more. Its dark brother, Hypersomnia, drags its victims down into endless drowning sleep, while Narcolepsy strikes like a rattler, sudden and without mercy.

Deep in the hypothalamus, in the terrible machinery of the brain, neurons fire their ancient signals. They speak in tongues of orexin, these messengers of wake and sleep. The scientists, they took their mice and watched these neurons dance. GABAB receptors, they said, like gatekeepers at the edge of consciousness. When they forced these gates open with their chemicals - baclofen they called it - sleep came like a flood. The mice slept, and in their sleep they carried secrets about our own darkness.

But the truth of sleep lies deeper than receptors and neurons. It runs in bloodlines, passes from father to son like eye color or the shape of hands. When these inherited gates are broken, sleep becomes a ghost, haunting but never touching, and the sleepless ones must drag themselves through their days like wounded animals. They sit in fluorescent-lit offices, stand at assembly lines, drive their children to school, all while carrying the weight of endless waking, their eyes burning like coals in the desert of consciousness.

He'd been there two and a half years or thereabouts, counting time in semesters like notches on a gun. The campus stretched vast and unforgiving before him, a concrete wilderness where souls wandered lost between buildings old as sin and new as tomorrow's promise. That first year they'd put him in East Halls, far out on the eastern edge where civilization gave way to the stadium's hulking shadow. The walk from Stuart Hall to Willard was a pilgrimage of sorts, twenty-five minutes through whatever hell the Pennsylvania weather chose to unleash, and it was always choosing.

An old graduate, not much older than himself but carrying the wisdom of years past, spoke of times when East Halls stood alone in a sea of empty land, like an island of brick and mortar in an ocean of nothing. Now that emptiness had been filled with the bones of progress - sports fields and buildings rising like monoliths from the earth, the Creamery and health services among them, apartment complexes circling like vultures on the periphery. The campus grew like a living thing, devouring space, making distance an enemy to be conquered.

The bicycle came as salvation. Not just the machine itself but the idea of it, the promise of freedom in two wheels and a chain. He'd heard tell of a friend who'd returned to cycling after years away, speaking of it like a man who'd found religion again. Bikes are great, the friend had said, the words carrying the weight of prophecy. For a time they weren't cool but they were always right, always true.

He lived off campus now, far as any dormitory, maybe farther. The bicycle had been an investment in survival. Thomas building loomed twenty-five minutes distant by foot, but the bike cut through time like a blade, reducing the journey to five minutes of pure velocity. Pollock Road lay between, a straight shot but treacherous, populated by wandering souls and metal beasts. Walking was for those with time to burn, and time was a currency he couldn't spare. Each day without the bike would cost him forty minutes, time multiplied across days and weeks until it became a burden too heavy to bear.

They came for the machines and the money both. In the pages of his testament Huxley had seen it coming like a storm rolling across the plains of human consciousness, dark and vast and terrible. The people in his vision stood as cattle in their pens, branded with letters that marked their worth, their minds scrubbed clean of individual thought by the relentless whispers in the night. They called it conditioning. A word clean as bleached bone but beneath it lay something darker.

The World Controller stood above them all like some pagan god of old, dispensing happiness like communion wafers, hollow and tasteless but necessary all the same. Through the lens of Marx's prophecies you could see the truth of it, written in the blood of human autonomy. Words like homogeny and reification rattled like dead men's teeth in the skull of progress.

The false consciousness lay upon them like a burial shroud. The lower orders - Deltas, Gammas, all of them marked and numbered like livestock - moved through their days in a soma-induced haze, buying and spending and rutting with mechanical precision. They knew nothing of their chains. The Alphas and Betas watched from their towers of privilege, knowing but not speaking, seeing but not acting. Bernard alone stood witness, though his testimony fell on ears stopped with cotton and comfort.

There was no love in this brave new world. The characters moved through their assigned roles like marionettes, strings pulled by unseen hands. The men spoke of women as if describing machinery - pneumatic, functional, interchangeable parts in the great engine of society. The women catalogued their couplings like accountants tallying figures in a ledger. Each caste accepted their place with the quiet resignation of the damned, consuming their allotted pleasures, obeying their prescribed commandments, walking in lockstep toward some horizon they could neither see nor understand.

Four years back I sat in a room where they spoke of Islam. The walls were white and clean like bones bleached in the desert sun. Men and women argued whether this faith carried violence in its heart. The question echoes still, louder now than before, like thunder rolling across empty plains.

Since the towers fell I watched how the papers and screens changed their tune. First with venom and spite then with a sweetness that seemed false as a serpent's smile. Strange days these are when a man named Barack Obama, carrying Muslim blood in his veins, could reach for the highest seat in this land.

The Prophet's tale sits heavy in my hands. Words that dont match the blood-soaked history I know. They tell of a gentle man but history whispers different truths. In the old stories he rode with sword and flame, making converts of the conquered. Yet here in these pages he walks humble and meek, waiting for men to find truth in his words like water in the desert.

The writers laid their words careful as trappers setting snares. They painted miracles that mirror the Christ's own works. Mutton and milk multiplied like loaves and fishes. A mockery. They stole the holy stories and dressed them in different clothes, thinking none would notice the theft.

They built their truth on whispers. One man telling another who told another still, like wind carrying dust across empty places. Each story passed through many mouths before finding paper, and truth has a way of changing shape when it travels so far.

What burns worst is how they made him holy. Gentle. Wise. But history carries darker truths, written in blood and steel. I wonder if the faithful know what darkness sleeps in their prophet's past, what violence birthed their faith. Some truths are better left in shadow, but they have a way of finding light.

They cast off his teachings like old clothes. Left them there in the dust of time while the world spun on and men spoke of things they knew nothing about. The truth of it was simple enough. Christianity had wandered far from where it began, like some nomadic tribe lost in the wasteland, each generation straying further from the path until they forgot there ever was one.

Now the world turns different. Progressive they call it. The old ones still cling to their ways like driftwood in a flood but their numbers grow thin and their voices grow weak. There's a awakening coming. Like thunder rolling across the plains. People wanting to strip away the layers of doctrine built up like rust on iron, wanting to find what lies beneath. Might take years. Might take centuries. Don't matter none. It'll come just the same.

They'll peel back time like the skin of some ancient fruit. Layer by layer. Until there ain't nothing left but what he said. What he meant. Before the others came with their own ideas about what God wanted. When it comes it'll sweep through like wildfire. Through the cities and the towns. Through the old world and the new. The church'll still stand but it'll be different. Like a house stripped down to its bones.

Where there was many there'll be one. Where there was difference there'll be sameness. It's happened before. Rome hunted Christians like wolves then bent its knee to the cross. Black men went from chains to power. The wheel turns and what was down comes up and up comes down.

They'll read his words different too. Not like reading from some ledger but like reading smoke signals against the sky. Looking for meaning behind meaning.

Back before all this there was only the Jews. Back when Rome first marched into Jerusalem like they owned it. Sixty-three years before the birth of Christ. The Jews weren't one people then neither. Sadducees. Pharisees. Essenes. Zealots. Common folk. All of them different as night and day but all reading from the same book. One God. One truth. One holy text. That's how it started.

There aint no mercy in the hearts of men. The Jungle shows us this truth plain as day and black as night. Deep in their cores men harbor only greed and self-preservation, a darkness that spreads like poison through their veins. They look not below them save to crush what lies beneath their boots.

You see it clearest in them factory owners and their kind. They build their empires on broken backs and spilled blood, caring nothing for the cost. Their ambitions rise like great black monoliths against the dying sky, and Sinclair writes of it thus: "The line of buildings stood clear-cut and black against the sky; here and there out of the mass rose the great chimneys, with the river of smoke streaming away to the end of the world." That smoke carries with it the dreams and lives of thousands, drifting off into nothingness while the masters count their coins.

These men care nothing for the destruction they wrought. Not for the poisoned earth nor the fouled waters running thick with offal from their killing floors. The air itself turned rank with the stench of progress, and still they pushed on, driven by that ancient hunger that knows no satisfaction.

Their workers was nothing more than cattle to them. Expendable. Replaceable. "A seething cauldron of jealousies and hatreds," Sinclair called it, where "no man counted for anything against a dollar." They'd work a man till his bones cracked then cast him aside like a spent shell casing, no more thought given than to the hogs they butchered.

Them that lived and died in Packingtown knew no salvation. No law protected them, no angel watched over their suffering. The unions that claimed to be their salvation was nothing but vultures picking at the same corpse. They was slaves in all but name, bound not by chains but by poverty and desperation. "Here is a population," the truth rings out, "low-class and mostly foreign, hanging always on the verge of starvation and dependent for its opportunities of life upon the whim of men every bit as brutal and unscrupulous as the old-time slave drivers." And so it was, and so it remains, the dark heart of man beating its terrible rhythm through the ages.

They say Dreamland was one of them poems Poe held dear above the others. Like a father with his favorite child. In it he wrote of Thulé, that word appearing twice like dark sentinels at the edges of his verse, and Mabbott in his wisdom traced it back to Virgil who spoke of some forsaken island past Britain where the known world gave way to darkness and myth. But there was something else. Something closer. The German scribes had caught Poe's eye and held it.

The truth of it lay in how Poe knew Goethe's work, deep and terrible. Arndt, in his scholarly wanderings through Poe's Politian and Goethe's Mignon, saw the ghost of one in the other, like a man recognizing his own reflection in muddy water.

Oxford tells us Goethe was a giant among men who birthed Faust into the world in two parts, the first in 1808 and the last in 1832 when death finally claimed him. Hidden in that second part was "The King of Thulé," a dark tale of a king whose queen passed leaving him naught but a goblet. He drank deep of his grief until the cup overflowed with tears and memory. When his time came he gave away all he owned save that cursed vessel. Walked to the edge of the world and cast it into the hungry sea before closing his eyes one final time. That king and the wraith in Dreamland might have been brothers, both shaped by loss and drink and darkness.

Grattan took Faust and made it his own in 1842, not a year before Poe wrote of Thule in "The Pit and the Pendulum." Like blood calling to blood. Twice Poe conjured Thule in his writings, once in Pendulum and twice more in Dreamland like bookends holding up worlds of shadow. Read them together, Goethe's King and Poe's Dreamland, and you'll see the same darkness reflected. The speaker walks through places where color goes to die, where ghosts of dead friends whisper on the wind, where loneliness has made its kingdom. Just as Goethe's king walked through his own private hell after his queen's passing.

Poe knew Goethe as sure as night knows day, if only through Tennyson whom he praised like a prophet. But there were other ways Goethe's words might have found him, carried on the winds of countless retellings after the master's death.

The law speaks of malice and rights and consequences but the truth of it lay deeper than any statute writ by men in their towers of concrete and steel. In the florescent-lit aisles of D&D Markets the applesauce spread like some viscous harbinger, a portent of what was to come while Martin sat in his office eating his dinner with the same methodical indifference that marked all his days.

They had told him twice. Wayne first and then Haddigan quarter hour later, their voices carrying the same warning through the stale store air but Martin had dismissed them both with words that hung like lead in the empty space between them. Didn't have time for customer complaints, he'd said, though time was all there was and all there ever would be.

When Palmer fell it was as if the world had been waiting for just such a moment. Her body twisted and broke against the hard tile floor like something preordained, her spine crackling with a sound like dry kindling. The fifth such falling that year, or perhaps the sixth, as if the store itself had developed a taste for broken bodies and spilled blood.

The question before the court was one of punishment beyond mere compensation, of whether Martin's disregard carried within it that special kind of darkness the law calls malice. The California code spoke of oppression and fraud and malice like ancient runes carved in legal stone, demanding proof of despicable conduct or willing disregard for the safety of others. And there was something in Martin's actions that spoke to this, something in the way he sat eating while knowing what lay in wait in his aisles, knowing what had come before and what would surely come again.

The judge would see it. In the cold fluorescent light of the courtroom he would recognize that special kind of darkness that lives in men who watch others suffer while they sup, who hear warnings and turn away, who know the consequences and choose them anyway. For this was not mere negligence but something older, something that spoke to the darkness that lives in all men's hearts.

The wanting lived in her like a hunger. Started when she was fourteen and hadnt left her yet. Three years gone and still it gnawed. Not a thing she needed now but someone and yet the boys who came calling stirred nothing in her heart. They made their clumsy advances like yearling colts testing weak legs but she turned from them all. She studied this emptiness like a crow picking through bones but found no answers there. Just the endless wanting and the questions that followed behind like pallbearers at a funeral that wouldnt end.

The house was quiet most days. Her parents moved through the rooms like ghosts barely disturbing the air. No shouting. No tears. When words did rise between them and their daughter they were about her wildness, her need to run free like some unbroken mare. She carried a fire in her that burned bright against their stillness but folk took to her anyway. Something in that flame drew them close despite the risk of burning.

Then came the day when quiet broke. A cry cut through the morning air sharp as a blade. Kitchen way. Her mothers voice twisted into something wrong. She ran calling out mama mama but the only answer was pain wrapped in short breaths. Found her mother laid out on the tile like something fallen from a great height. Touch gentle as prayer on her mothers shoulder. Take me to the hospital child the words coming broken and scattered like birds shot from the sky. She gathered her mother up blessed now for the strength in her arms. Carried her like something precious and fragile to the waiting car.

The hospital air was thick with death and antiseptic but she noticed none of it. Her world had narrowed to her mothers pain and the need to end it. Called out and white coats came running their faces masks of concern. They took her mother away on a wheeled bed and left her there in the waiting room with nothing but time and worry for company.

All this because a vase set too high needed reaching and a stepstool proved treacherous as any snake in the garden.

They sought truth in numbers and blood. The Mediterranean way of eating, ancient as the stones themselves, whispered promises of longer life through the statistics. Not in words but in the absence of dead hearts, in the flowing of clean blood through untainted vessels. They called it aMed, this scoring of meals, this counting of plants and fish and the oils that men had pressed from fruit since time before memory.

The old studies spoke their piece. Numbers carved into ledgers showing how men who ate from the earth's abundance, who shunned the heavy fats of beasts, lived longer. Their hearts beat stronger. But none had looked deep into the darkness of the stroke, that silent killer that steals mind and movement alike.

Seventy-four thousand eight hundred and eighty-six women they watched. Nurses all of them, scattered across eleven states like seeds in the wind. For twenty years they marked their eating in questionnaires, six times from 1984 to 2004, documenting each morsel as if writing their own salvation. They were faithful in their reporting, these women, more than ninety-five in every hundred staying true to the end.

The counters of numbers verified everything. When death came they searched through papers and certificates, autopsy reports telling tales of failed hearts and blocked vessels. Some they called probable, when the papers weren't there to tell the tale. Seventeen percent of strokes, twenty-four percent of heart failures, marked down in their ledgers like notches on a gun.

They tracked everything. Weight and smoke and pills. The movement of bodies in leisure and the changes that time brings to women's flesh. The numbers spoke of protection. Those who followed the old ways, eating as their ancestors did from the Mediterranean shores, they lived longer. Two thousand three hundred ninety-one hearts failed, one thousand seven hundred sixty-three minds darkened by stroke, one thousand seventy-seven souls claimed by the combined assault. But those who ate from the earth's bounty, they stood stronger. The numbers said so. Zero point seven one, they wrote in their books. A mathematical blessing, a ward against death.

Hitler lives, the sign said. Just that and nothing more upon the cardboard held aloft by the girl actor who'd once played pregnant in that picture show. She stood there in the gray morning like some soothsayer of old bearing portents and auguries.

They called it Burma though that wasnt its name no more. A land of temples and soldiers where men in ochre robes walked the streets in silence until they didnt. Until the streets ran red with their blood and the monasteries lay broken and burning in the perpetual dusk of that strange country. The government men had come up through ranks like carrion birds ascending, nineteen sixty two it was, and they ruled with iron and lead and all manner of cruelty that men devise when power fills their gullets.

In the year two thousand and seven the monks rose up. Saffron Revolution they called it though revolution it wasnt, just death dealt out like playing cards in some cosmic game where the house always wins. A Japanese man with a camera lay dying in the street while they watched. Thirteen dead said the papers but the colonel who fled knew different. Thousands, he said. Thousands.

These things aint new. Since men first gathered in tribes there been those who'd rule absolute. Roman emperors who claimed kinship with gods. Japanese kings who were gods themselves. Even now our own president takes counsel from prophets and madmen who speak in tongues of power and control.

The examples lay scattered through time like broken pottery. Tiananmen where tanks rolled over students who dared to dream. Rwanda where neighbor killed neighbor until the streets stank of death. Hitler's own Reich where the crematoriums burned day and night without ceasing. All of it written in blood on pages that history turns with indifferent hands.

The shadow of Duke Ellington looms long across the wasteland of jazz, not just in years but in the way he shaped and molded his orchestra like some dark craftsman at his forge. His piano work whispers through the compositions like wind through dead grass, but as architect of sound he built cathedrals of brass and wood where soloists could wander like prophets in the wilderness. He knew the voices of his men, knew them like a father knows his sons, and he wrote for their souls as much as their instruments. The framework he built was both prison and liberation, the tightly wound phrases and loose improvisations existing in the same space like light and dark at twilight.

The scholars speak of Creole Love Call as if speaking of ancient scripture, noting how he made the human voice into something otherworldly, stripped of words and meaning save what the soul could conjure. Six times the piece turns upon itself like a serpent consuming its tail. First comes the voice, pure as spring water then rough as desert stone, calling to the reeds that answer like lost children. Then the trumpet emerges from the darkness, muted and blue as midnight, followed by the clarinet that climbs toward heaven while the piano walks beneath it like a shadow. The full band rises up like a great beast, brass and reed speaking in tongues, until the fifth turning when everything reaches toward something unseen and terrible and beautiful. In the end the voice returns, growling like some creature that has forgotten it was once human, and the trombone speaks the final dissonant words like a priest delivering last rites.

A year later he conjured Hot and Bothered from the void, Miley's trumpet and Cox's voice speaking to each other like lovers in a dead language. And when It Don't Mean a Thing emerged from the darkness, Nanton's trombone spoke first, as if announcing the coming of something that could not be named. This was Ellington's way, to take the human and make it instrument, to take the brass and make it flesh, until you could no longer tell where one ended and the other began.

They come to us like questions in the dark. How the beasts of field and forest take their shapes and why. What forces bind them to their forms like prisoners to their chains. In 1917 Thompson wrote of how even the learned men of science had not yet begun to speak of living things in the tongue of numbers and equations and even now his words ring true across the wasteland of years.

The shells lie before us like calcified histories. Each one a testament to some ancient geometry that we cannot name. We study them, these remnants of Prunum, these spiral tombs of the creatures that once dwelt within. We gather their ghosts through machines that peer through their walls with invisible light and we feed these spectral measurements to newer machines that speak in electricity and silicon.

The shell is a prison built by its inmate, constructed in slow circles through time and space. Three hundred and sixty degrees of eternal return. The whorls spiral like a rope around nothing, around an axis that exists only in theory, in the mind. The columella stands sentinel at the center of it all. Each revolution grows according to some mathematical truth that we can only glimpse, like seeing shapes in smoke. The sutures mark time like notches on a prisoner's wall.

We arrange them in our taxonomies. Apical. Basal. Apertural. Abapertural. Words we use to impose order on chaos. We count the whorls like counting rings in a tree, measuring quarter turns as if such precision matters in the face of geological time. The aperture traces its path through space like a bullet through the dark, leaving behind only its calcified wake.

In the end we reduce it all to numbers. Coordinates. Trajectories. As if we could capture the essence of life in equations. As if we could understand the mind of God through mathematics. But the shells remain what they are. Silent witnesses to processes we can only pretend to comprehend.

The dead children of Indonesia lay like dark seeds in the earth, their numbers unchanging through the years, a grim testament carved in stone. The nation moved forward in some ways, meeting goals for water and clean places to shit, but the mothers and their young ones kept dying just the same, their blood seeping into soil that cared nothing for millennium goals or government promises.

They said more births now had someone who knew the old ways, seven of ten maybe, women who'd learned their craft from their mothers and grandmothers before them. But when the blood came, really came, these women stood helpless as the rest, watching life drain away in crimson rivers. Numbers on paper meant nothing to death. It took what it wanted.

In the cities they cut women open to save them, but not many. Four in hundred maybe. Out in the places where dirt roads turned to mud and electricity came and went like a fickle god, fewer still. The rich got their medicine and their doctors. The poor got their prayers. Twenty-seven percent difference between them, the bureaucrats said, as if poverty could be measured in clean decimals instead of dead children.

They argued about it in offices with air conditioning, whether to build special programs or fix the whole broken machine. Vertical approaches, they called them, like ladders to heaven. But every ladder they built seemed to steal from another, and the forms and papers multiplied like rats in a granary. Money flowed to AIDS while babies died of diarrhea, and the doctors chased the dollars like crows following a plow. Nothing changed except the numbers on the reports, and those numbers were written in blood.

The music they call Popular has grown wild and untamed these hundred years past, spreading like windblown seed across the land until no man could count its varieties. And these varieties bred new varieties and those bred still more until the names themselves became a babel of confusion. Rap and rock and country and jazz and folk, each spawning children darker and stranger than their fathers.

Among these bastard sons none grew more twisted and manifold than the thing they called Heavy Metal. It came slouching out of the darkness forty years ago and in its wake followed legions. Each new breed carrying some mark of its sire but warped and changed like creatures born in atomic fire. The darkness in it spoke to something in men's souls and they took it and shaped it to their own designs, each new shaping breeding yet more shapes until the very thing that spawned them all became impossible to name.

Now the metal walks among us in countless forms, like some demon that can wear any face it chooses. To understand this thing you must go back to where it began, back to the source of the darkness. For metal aint just music. It's a movement born in shadow and raised on blood and thunder.

They made it louder, heavier, more violent than what came before. The players were virtuosos of chaos, their instruments howling like the damned. And there were drugs, yes. In those mid-seventies years when the psychedelics flowed like water and men's minds turned to strange horizons. They made records that sound like dispatches from hell itself, blame it on the drugs if you want but the darkness was there already, waiting. The pretty music of those days couldn't speak to what was coming. But metal could. Metal did. Like some dark reflection of the Romantic composers of old, it reached into the shadows of men's souls and pulled forth something terrible and true.

In the years before the dreamers took to their canvases with their strange visions the man called Rousseau had already begun to paint his own. The dreams came to him like thieves in the night and he put them down with careful strokes as if marking the passage of something ancient and terrible. The Dream they called it. Nineteen hundred and ten. A woman lost in some savage paradise while beasts with eyes like burning coals watched from the darkness of the jungle. But the real dream was his own and it gnawed at him like hunger. Recognition. Acceptance. The approval of men who painted in ways he could not understand but desperately wished to join.

He was born to a tinsmith in Laval where the spring rains fell hard against the slate roofs and the streets ran with mud. No teacher ever showed him how to hold a brush or mix colors or capture the light that fell across the world like God's own thoughts. For forty years he collected tolls from travelers while the art lived inside him like some trapped animal trying to claw its way free. They called him douanier though that wasnt right. His first wife Clémence died and took eight babies with her to the cold ground leaving only Julia behind. The grief sat in him like lead and he turned to painting like a man turns to whiskey, hoping to drown something that cannot be drowned.

He worked in the shadow of giants. While Matisse and the others carved their names into history with wild colors and shapes that defied God's own design Rousseau labored in his simple way trying to make pictures that would please the men who decided such things. Matisse feared convention like it was a poison but Rousseau sought it like salvation. Two men walking different roads in the same dark wood. One running from what the other was running toward.

The folk painters heart beat in him true as any clock. He painted what he knew and what he dreamed and what he feared all at once and the pictures came out strange and wonderful though he never meant them to be. His dreams of acceptance lay in him like stones but the pictures that came from his hands were something else entirely. Something wild. Something true.

They say truth and beauty walk together like old companions on a dusty road. Been that way since before any living soul drew breath. Keats knew it when he wrote them words about the urn, beauty being truth and truth being all we need know in this world. Most things a man learns come from books or hard living but the knowing of right and wrong, the seeing of what's beautiful, that comes from somewhere deeper. Like an old well that ain't got no bottom.

You can study it all you want. Write down rules about what makes something right or pretty. But they're just words on paper, trying to catch smoke in your hands. Take that painting, the Mona Lisa. Folk talk about shadow and light, about what was happening in Italy back then, but that ain't really it. When someone loves a thing, really loves it, first words out their mouth is always something like "there's just something about it." Rest comes after, like trying to explain why you love your momma.

O'Connor, she knew. Said some things can only be told in stories because regular talk won't do. Like trying to describe the taste of water to someone who ain't never drunk none. Same goes for knowing right from wrong. Wittgenstein said ethics can't be spoke of proper, and he wasn't wrong. There's something in both art and right living that sits beyond words, like a far-off mountain you can see but never reach.

Way I figure it, that's why stories and morals run so close together, like two streams joining in the valley. They both hit us somewhere deep, somewhere we can feel but can't point to. Literature especially. McKean had it right when he said books carry moral weight same as life does. Can't live without choosing between right and wrong, and can't tell stories without doing the same. That's what makes them matter. That's what makes them true.

The Germany that stands now rises like a sentinel, unified and stark against the heavens, its essence flowing from the shadow-kept valleys of München where the alps loom black and ancient to the cold waters of Kiel where the Baltic meets the shore in eternal conflict. This essence, this blood-memory, courses through the veins of cities from Köln where the Rhine cuts deep and merciless, through the heartland to Dresden where the Elbe winds like a steel serpent through Saxon stone. And in this land where darkness and light wage their endless war, the roots run deep into soil watered by the blood of tribes long forgotten.

Germania. The word itself carries weight like old bones in the earth. Men argue its meaning like crows fighting over carrion, each pecking at truth with black beaks. Tacitus, that Roman who peered into the darkness beyond the empire's reach, spoke of the Tungrians who crossed the Rhine with fire and steel, becoming Germans in the crossing. Caesar too marked them in his writings, ink flowing like blood across parchment as he recorded their raids, their savage dance across borders that meant nothing to them. The word itself perhaps meant neighbor in the tongue of the Gauls, or maybe it spoke of the spear they carried, the ger, death-dealer in the hands of warriors. Or perhaps it rose from garim, a scream in the Old Irish night, for these were a people who made the darkness echo with their war-cries.

Tacitus wrote of them as if writing of wolves or winter storms, creatures born of the land itself. Not mixed with others, he said, for who would choose such wilderness, such brutal skies, such a land that wore its hostility like a crown? The Germans were aboriginal, sprung from soil and ice and darkness.

The Romans came and went like summer storms, taking what they could carry, leading their legions into the depths of Germania only to retreat again to their marble cities and heated baths. And the Germans remained, trading with the empire that feared them, serving in its armies while keeping their own savage hearts. They dwelt in the borderlands like shadows at the edge of firelight, taking what they needed from the land and from Rome itself, patient as winter, eternal as the forests that bore them.

In the dark heart of Twelfth Night there dwells a truth about masks and the wearing of them, how they serve their purpose like a knife serves its wielder but in time will turn against the flesh that holds them. The shedding of such guises becomes necessary lest the wearer lose themselves to the void that lies between what is and what seems to be. But there aint no easy way to cast off what's become a second skin and them that's been deceived may turn cold as winter stone or hot as desert fury when the truth comes calling.

The matter of gender masquerade carries its own peculiar burden, like a snake that eats its own tail, forever asking why. Why does the soul seek to shed its given form and take up another? Viola speaks plain enough about it: "I'll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count..." The words hang in the air like smoke from a dying fire.

She come to these foreign shores alone and afraid and took up man's clothing like armor against the world's malice. But such protection carries its own poison. It sets her apart from her own kind, leaves her to walk alone among women who might have been sisters to her. And Olivia, God help her, sees in Viola's disguise what she wants to see, calling out "Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay." The words fall like dead birds from her lips. And there's Orsino too, speaking words that cut like broken glass: "Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me."

Maybe them that read these words now might see something deeper, like looking into a well at midnight. Maybe they'd say this tale shows how lies can sometimes midwife truth into the world, especially in Olivia and Orsino's case. Their desires lay buried like bones in the desert until Viola's deception dug them up. Some might wonder if Olivia's heart truly yearned for women all along, but that aint likely what Shakespeare meant. More like he was mocking them that judge love by its container rather than its contents.

You can see it clear as day when Olivia turns her affections from Cesario to Sebastian quick as a rattler strikes, and speaks to Viola like blood kin: "A sister, you are she." The words ring true at last, like a bell in the darkness that finally finds its proper tone.

They spoke of the German rule in whispers. Of cruelties visited upon the Ovaherero and the Nama peoples in that sunscorched land they called South West Africa. But empires aint built on simple tales and the Germans ruled different lands different ways and some flourished while others withered beneath the weight of their governance.

In the east where the British come to rule in 1919 they found natives who could read and write and cipher numbers like educated men. Same in Kamerun where even the white men spoke well of what the Germans had done. But South West Africa was different. Something darker there.

The missionaries come with their books and their crosses but the government gave them nothing. No help. No coin. While the white children got their schools built fine with government money and the mission schools for whites got what they needed too. These things cast long shadows and while other colonies had natives who could read and write and make their way in the white man's world South West Africa remained in darkness. Its people untouched. Unlearned. Unable to read the very papers that marked their fate.

Men wrote about these things. German men mostly, in the early days of the century, putting down in their own tongue what they saw in these far places. Later others come. English speakers who looked at how different colonies fared different fates. Cohen was one. He wrote about the schools in South West Africa and East Africa both, trying to make sense of why one flourished while the other failed. He said it was the settlers that made the difference. Too many whites in South West Africa wanting to keep things their way.

The land there wasnt like the other colonies. Not so hot. Not so wet. Desert mostly but liveable if you were white and determined. By 1913 fifteen thousand whites had made it their home while East Africa, the next most settled place, had barely five thousand. They come for the temperate air and the promise of mastery over the land and its people. And master it they did.

They rode forth across that contested earth, these two nations, like ancient enemies bound by blood and soil. From 1836 to 1893 they circled each other like wounded wolves, fifty-seven years of malice carved into the very ground beneath them. The war came in 1846, as wars do, and the American forces descended upon Mexico like locusts, stripping away Texas and the Southwest territories, leaving behind nothing but dust and memory.

The border between them was a wound that would not heal. Like all neighbors cursed by proximity they found in each other a mirror of their own fears, their own hatreds. Their differences ran deep as burial grounds - God and custom and the old ways setting them apart like oil and water in a jar. Cuba too stood watching from across the water, another thorn in the American flesh, while the rest of Latin America kept its distance, wise perhaps in its caution.

Religion lay between them like a rusted blade. The Protestant Americans carried their prejudices from the old world, wearing their distrust of Catholics like armor, just as their English forebears had done. The Spanish shadow fell long across Mexico, and in its darkness old hatred grew like weeds in untended fields.

Seventeen times they clashed in those bitter years, mostly over the border that cut through the land like a scar. Bandits and murderers moved across it like ghosts, striking at towns on both sides, until finally both nations sent their armies to stand watch over that invisible line. The rivalry died slow, like all ancient things must die, when Mexico fell into the economic embrace of its northern neighbor, American ambition turning from land to money, as it always does in the end.

The old ways changed. The old blood dried. But the memory remained, etched into the stones and the sand and the bones of all those who died in that time when two nations stared across a line drawn in dust, each seeing in the other a darkness they feared in themselves.

Fifteen years back the sickness came. Not gradual like winter but sudden and complete, a thing I'd never heard tell of before it took me.

I was a nurse then. Chose it out of some hollow need for safety, the kind that gets bred into you when you're young and afraid. They'd say you'll always find work cause folks'll always be dying or trying not to. So I buried deeper things, dreams of science and truth-telling, and took up with the sick and dying instead.

There I was at forty-six. Alone. No money to speak of and work become impossible as breath to a hanged man. Fifteen years living on government alms and now nothing remains that's truly mine. Each day comes like a thief in the night, stealing what little security remains. Nothing certain anymore except this one truth: that without my blood kin and the few true friends, I'd have been gone to dust. When the real darkness comes it strips you bare of all pretense of strength.

Life's got its catastrophes waiting, big and small like wolves in the night. No matter how you prepare some storms are too big to weather alone. Ain't no guarantee written in stone or sky.

The government's basket's got holes and the bottom's falling out, sure as sunrise. But better we learn to trust each other again than each man digging his own grave in the backyard calling it shelter. They talk about rugged individualism like it built this nation, but that ain't the truth of it. What kept our ancestors breathing was mercy and respect and the sharing of what little they had. Them wagon trains didn't cross the mountains one by one.

So lay in your stores. Keep your matches dry and your water clean. Stack your canned goods like gold bars if you want. Plant your garden if the earth'll have you. But while you're doing all that surviving, remember your neighbor's light in the window. Might be the only thing between you and the dark when it comes.

He was born a prince in the old world, in times when men still believed the earth was flat and the heavens hung low like a tapestry of black velvet studded with cold fire. They would later call him Buddha. The years counted backward twenty five hundred times since then, since he walked away from wealth and crown to seek what lay beyond the veil of human suffering. What he found became Buddhism and the Theravada followed, pure as mountain water, orthodox as stone.

The thing that was then aint the thing that is now. In Sri Lanka they cut water once each year, monks and common folk gathered like dark birds at the edge of sacred pools, performing rituals the Buddha never spoke of. Time changes all things. Even truth. Even doctrine. The Theravada Buddhist folk, them that wear robes and them that dont, have watched their beliefs shift like sand in desert winds, pushed by forces within and without, some meaning harm and others meaning nothing at all but bringing change regardless.

Words matter here. Internal is what comes from inside the Buddhasasana, be it monk or layman that brings it. External is all else, the outsider, the stranger, the other. Some forces come with teeth bared and claws extended, seeking to tear down what Buddha built. These are hostile. Others come blank-faced and indifferent, neither meaning good nor ill, though they may bring either. These are benign. Remember these words. They'll come again.

The heart of it all beats steady beneath. Three jewels they seek refuge in: Buddha, Dhamma, Sangha. The Dhamma lives in three baskets of ancient words. Suttas telling tales and teachings. Vinaya speaking law. Abhidhamma reaching into the spaces between spaces where metaphysics dwell. They speak of Anatta, the great emptiness where soul should be. Of Dukkha, the suffering that runs through all things like dark threads through pale cloth. Of Anicca, how nothing lasts, nothing stays, nothing holds. Know these and you might break free of Sansara, that wheel that turns and turns, grinding life into death into life again. Break free of want and hate and the fog that clouds mens minds. The Vinaya tells how to live. Five rules for common folk: kill not, lie not, steal not, keep your loins in check, stay clear of drink and drugs that cloud the mind. Monks got more rules. Many more. But at the center of it all stand four truths like stone pillars holding up the sky. Life is suffering. Want brings suffering. Suffering can end.

original_texts:
Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
	 chose a piece of property from a real estate website and researched available government programs to see what options a small farmer might realistically have for mitigating costs and preserving wildlife-friendly operations.  As a model of what somebody farming this land might attempt to achieve, I located an organic farm in the same area.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are. In their actions and the consequences of those actions is where their true character lies.  In “The Scarlet Ibis”, two brothers explore this theme, and all of the raging emotions that accompany it. Throughout a lush, vividly described landscape, these two boys set out on a futile journey. Bitter disappointment clashes with intense pride in the climactic scene, and only one brother escapes with his life. The theme is expressed through direct characterization of the protagonist, Doodle, and their interactions with each other, as well as through the narrator’s point of view, which communicates the complex feelings experienced by the protagonist and his view of the world around him, both of which are heavy influences on his actions.
	The protagonist’s actions can all be summed up by one key emotion: pride. From the time he and his little brother, Doodle, first go out together, to their final, fateful excursion, the protagonist feels resentment towards Doodle. He had wanted a brother whom he could teach all of his worldly skills, like “…holding my breath, running, jumping, or climbing the vines in Old Woman Swamp…” He wanted a brother who could fill the role of “…someone to race to Horsehead Landing…and someone to perch with in the top fork of the great pine behind the barn…” Obviously these things are impossible, given Doodle’s condition. Doodle was born with an extremely weak heart, making in unlikely he would even survive. Even then, it was nearly impossible that he would ever participate in vigorous physical activity. What a blow to the young protagonist, his head filled with wild fantasies, to have all of those dreams crushed in an instant. In fact, he is even shown to bear some anger towards the small child, as he recalls beginning to contemplate killing him by suffocating him with a pillow. What kind of child would have the presence of mind to consider infanticide? However, his heart melts when the small child smiles at him. Such a simple act gave the protagonist such hope! This shows that his conviction probably was not very strong. In the back of his mind, he had an instinctive love for his brother.

The human brain is a complicated, creative information-processing system. As technology advanced from primitive to modern, the metaphors used to describe the brain also advanced. Initially, it was compared to a wax tablet, then to a sheet of papyrus, then to a book, and most recently, to a computer. As you learn about the brain, keep in mind that the usefulness of these metaphors is limited and can lead to erroneous conclusions.
Information processing starts with input from the sensory organs, which transform physical stimuli such as touch, heat, sound waves, or photons of light into electrochemical signals. The sensory information is repeatedly transformed by the algorithms of the brain in both bottom-up and top-down processing. For example, when looking at a picture of a black box on a white background, bottom-up processing puts together very simple information such as color, orientation, and where the borders of the object are – where the color changes significantly over a short space – to decide that you are seeing a box. Top-down processing uses the decisions made at some steps of the bottom-up process to speed up your recognition of the box. Top-down processing in this example might help you identify the object as a black box rather than a box-shaped hole in the white background.
Once information is processed to a degree, an attention filter decides how important the signal is and which cognitive processes it should be made available to. For example, although your brain processes every blade of grass when you look down at your shoes, a healthy attention filter prevents you from noticing them individually. In contrast, you might pick out your name, even when spoken in a noisy room. There are many stages of processing, and the results of processing are modulated by attention repeatedly.
In order for the brain to process information, it must first be stored. There are multiple types of memory, including sensory, working, and long-term. First, information is encoded. There are types of encoding specific to each type of sensory stimuli. For example, verbal input can be encoded structurally, referring to what the printed word looks like, phonemically, referring to what the word sounds like, or semantically, referring to what the word means. Once information is stored, it must be maintained. Some animal studies suggest that working memory, which stores information for roughly 20 seconds, is maintained by an electrical signal looping through a particular series of neurons for a short period of time. Information in long-term memory is hypothesized to be maintained in the structure of certain types of proteins.
There are numerous models of how the knowledge is organized in the brain, some based on the way human subjects retrieve memories, others based on computer science, and others based on neurophysiology. The semantic network model states that there are nodes representing concepts, and that the nodes are linked based on their relatedness. For example, in a semantic network, “chair” might be linked to “table,” which can be linked to “wooden,” and so forth.

In 2007, the United States of America fell into a crushing financial crisis. Unemployment increased, the housing market crashed, and many of America’s largest and most important corportations were left in ruin. This recession persists today, so we must ask the question: how did this crisis occur, and how can we stop it? In short, the financial crisis was created by selfish and naïve political decision-making that pressured banks and firms into issuing sub-prime loans into an already immature and unsufficient financial infrastructure. Meanwhile, Fannie Mae (FNMA) and Freddie Mac (FHLMC) were pressured to underwite and repackage these mortgages into CDO’s and CDS’. When borrowers defaulted on these loans, the banks were short on capital reserve and transferred this chaos onto the repacked mortgages that they had sold, and on to the rest of the economy.
	The financial crisis had its roots in 1999 of the Clinton era, as the President was aiming for a second term in office. He sought to extend his presidential tenure by augmenting his popularity. To accomplish this the Clinton administration relaxed lending restrictions, which helped to set the grim stage for the sub-prime crisis seven years later.  Steven Holmes of the New York Times reported in 1999, “Fannie Mae, the nation's biggest underwriter of home mortgages, has been under increasing pressure from the Clinton Administration to expand mortgage loans among low and moderate income people and felt pressure from stock holders to maintain its phenomenal growth in profits.” Holmes would go on to correctly foresee the consequences of these actions: “But the government-subsidized corporation may run into trouble in an economic downturn, prompting a government rescue similar to that of the savings and loan industry in the 1980s.” As detailed in the introduction, and as Holmes foresaw, ill-advised lending would certainly lead to the meltdown of the economy.
	Many factors combined to throw the economy into tailspin, one of which was the new and complex structure of mortgages. Adjustable-rate mortgages, mortgage-backed securities, and collateralized debt obligations (CDO’s) were all used extensively in the years leading up to the crisis, and only served to intertwine more sectors of the economy into the housing market. This led to U.S. households, and financial markets in general, to overleverage themselves in the housing market, leaving them extremely vulnerable to even small changes in price. 
	Indeed, the housing bubble burst, and the financial institutions that had bought these mortgage-backed securities were spited. The top five U.S. investment banks all together reported $4.1 trillion dollars of mortgage debts in 2007, which accounted for about 30% of the USA’s GDP. In the end, Bear Sterns and Merrill Lynch were sold exceptionally cheap, Lehman Brothers was dismantled, and Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley were forced to become commercial banks subjected to intense regulation. Fannie and Freddie were $5 trillion in mortgage debt, and were placed under government control in September 2008.

Ah, exposition.  That place in your story where you stretch your little writer's wings and take flight, astounding one and all with your magnetic, nay magical prose.  Or the part where your readers fall asleep and/or hit the "Back" button while cursing your name.  Dr. Merlin has been known to shout at her monitor when she finds herself in the middle of Too Much Information, and not even in the fun way.

Exposition is not your friend.

My gentle readers already know the basic writing tip, "Show, don't tell," but Dr. Merlin still stumbles into long passages of text where nothing happens, or worse, too much.  Exposition is the little devil sitting on your shoulder that says to get the history out of the way to get to the good parts (not to be confused with the devil sitting on the other shoulder urging the author to tell her audience every single detail of the childhoods of each character).

Exposition means telling the audience what happened, typically in simple prose.  In film, the exposition happens when one character tells another a core-dump of information ala "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner."  In fiction, the author's doing the telling.

An example is in order.  As you are reading a story, you are told that the heroine met her beloved at such a place and time, that they were married in a gala fashion, and that her husband was murdered in front of her eyes.  You would not expect this entire sequence to take two pages, during which time both he and she only get two lines of dialogue each.  You would expect the author to spend some time on the husband's character, evidencing by his speech and manner how deeply he loves his wife, and you would equally expect the heroine to show through big and small ways how much his presence in her life changed and enriched her (especially if the story were to tell you flat out later that this was the case).  A proper introduction to the husband's character would allow you to become emotionally involved with his fate and would give you insight into the heroine's character: what she saw in him, how deep their bond was, clues about her thoughts and beliefs and dreams as reflected through the prism of his eyes, and so on.  You would mourn his death with her, and so grow more connected to the heroine herself.

In short, you would expect meat on the simple bone of the storyline: "They met, they married, he died."

As a writer, you need to provide that meat.  (*looks at metaphor, sighs, plunges onward*)  Sometimes it is tempting to rush past certain things.  Perhaps you're introducing a new character and you know he used to be in the Air Force, and he's the night manager of a gas station now, and he was married twice, no kids, likes to go fishing on the weekends, secretly dreams of owning the gas station someday and had Eggs Benedict for breakfast.

I watched two newscast’s from Columbus, Ohio. The first one that was “live” was NBC 4 this morning (August 13, 2011). The lead story was about a man in Ashley, Ohio who had stabbed his wife, it did not state her name however his name was Shad Hostettler. They showed his mug shot and he looked like pure evil. They devoted only about two minutes to this story as it was developing. The only details they provide he had stabbed her multiple times and had been arrested. I think they spent an appropriate amount of time on this story. 
	The second story was about an early morning shooting of Travis Buyers, 18. He was shot in the Sharon Woods area and had been critically injured; there had been no arrests made at the time or any suspects. The SWAT Team was investigating the crime. This story seemed to be short, and I believe that might have been due to the fact this was a “black” man or a black neighborhood. I noticed (and have for years) that minorities are glossed over when they are a victim of a crime. If say a “white” child or adult is kidnapped or missing or a victim of a crime the media goes nuts; but if a minority person it’s lucky if it is even mentioned. 
	The next story was about the gunshot hole that had been found in the Med-Flight helicopter. Details were given about where they thought the incident happened. It had been determined that it was a .22 caliber bullet from a rifle that had hit the helicopter. Crime-Stoppers are offering a five-thousand dollar reward for tips that lead to the arrest of the shooter. 
	The next story was concerning the rain and thunderstorms predicted for Saturday afternoon. They said the temperatures would remain in the mid to low eighties for the weekend. The length of time was a little short, but they wanted to use it as a “teaser” so that you would stay tuned. 
	They also ran with a story about a robbery of a Clime Road UDF in Columbus. They said it was dark-skinned black man who robbed the store he was wearing a hoodie sweatshirt. They said he was about six-foot tall and weighed about one hundred and fifty pounds. I thought they devoted an unusual about of time emphasizing he was black and how dark he was. 
	Another story was about a Rene Rodriguez who was a convicted Texas Drug-Kingpin. He had been convicted of conspiring to distribute marijuana in large amounts to Ohio from Texas. One curious thing I noted, was instead of saying he was sentenced to twenty-five years in prison they said “300” months. I am not sure what the angle was there, whether they thought that sounded more harsh or what. They also mentioned he was a Hispanic man, I don’t believe that was really germane to the story.

An ETF, or exchange traded fund, is a security that is designed to track an index, a commodity or a basket of assets like an index fund, but is more flexible and trades like a stock on an exchange.  An ETF gives you the diversification of an index fund and the benefits of single stock ownership like the ability to sell short, buy on margin and purchase as few as a one share in any transaction.  Though these benefits are extremely attractive, the expense ratios of ETFs are far lower than those of the average mutual fund.  Unfortunately, there are some down sides, such as the need to pay a commission on any trade involving ETFs, just as you would pay on a stock order.  Another benefit of ETFs is the wide variety of funds available.  Though these benefits are clearly stated, it is always a good exercise for the savvy financial investor to evaluate whether stated benefits, like diversification, do indeed exist, and the extent to which they exist.  For the purposes of this effort, we will be examining the ETF IHF and comparing it against the top 10 holdings that comprise the ETF to determine whether the benefits of a owning a single ETF come close to the benefits of owning a diversified portfolio of the ten stocks and also whether or not there are better configurations of the same stocks that would provide a more optimal sharp ratio or return.
	In order to evaluate the ETF, it would become rather unwieldy to include every holding, therefore we have decided to include only the top ten holdings accounting for 63.58% of all the assets in the ETF.  Below are the top 10 holdings and the percentage of total assets.

	In order to gain an estimation of how well these ten stocks represent the ETF IHF as a whole, we can use the current % of assets, normalized to 100%, to  calculate the contributions of each stock to a portfolioâ€™s Beta and Return if the portfolio was made up entirely of these 10 stocks in the proportion that the ETF has established through their holdings.  The calculations of Beta and return are included in the below chart.

From the above chart it is evident that the return of a portfolio containing only the top 10 holdings is 6.11% higher than the ETF, a 16% increase in returns.  It is also evident that the Beta of the top ten holdings is .12 lower than the ETF as a whole.  From the results completed thus far, it seems that a portfolio of just the top 10 holdings could provide a higher return with a lower beta.  However, there is a possibility that the means of these two portfolios may not be statistically different from each other.
	In order to evaluate whether or not these portfolios are statistically different, the standard deviation of each of the top 10 stocks is determined and normalized to 100% in order to compare their accumulated standard deviation to that of the ETF IHF.

Referring back to Figure 17, there was a precipitous drop in commuter log submissions in the third month of the project. That was a bit disheartening, and it is hard to say why that might have happened.
