The Dream, a 1910 painting by the famous Post-Impressionist artist, represents not only a woman in awe at the wonders of the land she visits within a dream, but also Rousseau’s own personal dreams and goals as a painter. Since beginning his work, he dreamed of recognition, acceptance, and praise by other artists and art lovers, and found that he was faced with a difficult internal dilemma to achieve this aspiration. The Dream is Henri Rousseau’s work that best reflects his career-long internal struggle: to either conform to or mimic certain styles of painting in order to be accepted by the critical art world he so adored, or to allow himself to be creatively independent and unique, leaving his own path as he went.
Before one can analyze The Dream through this perspective, one must first be somewhat familiar with Rousseau’s biographical story. Henri Rousseau was born on May 21, 1844, in the town of Laval in northwest France. His father was a tinsmith and hardware dealer who “enjoyed bourgeois prosperity” (Shattuck 47). Growing up, he received no formal training in the arts; instead, he was employed until the age of forty working for France as a gabelou, or employee of the municipal toll service, although he received the misnomer sobriquet of douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). The death of his first wife, Clémence, which followed the deaths of eight infant children, left Rousseau with only one child, a daughter named Julia, and immense grief (Shattuck 49). He therefore hoped to take refuge in a new life and pursued painting to offer him comfort and fresh beginnings. Unlike contemporary colleagues of Rousseau who sentimentalize and romanticize the peasant in painting, he is essentially a folk painter and has the hopes and dreams of the average member of his class.
Rousseau’s obsession with being accepted by the art world is somewhat understandable when evaluated in context: as discussed, he was not only uneducated in the ways of formal painting and began his career at a much older age, but he was producing works at the same time as many other talented and better-known modern artists. Though working for many years already, Rousseau did not begin to receive proper recognition for his art until around the same time that Matisse had begun crafting a reputation as an artist. In the book Modern French Painters, author Jan Gordon asserts that the two, while technically competitors in the art arena, were different not only in style and subject matter but also their reasons for painting in the first place: “Matisse was a painter who conceived a terror of painting in a trite way, while Rousseau’s desire was to paint a picture so conventional that he would be admitted to the Artiste Français” (92).

Many a great thinker has postulated an intimate connection between ethics and aesthetics, between truth and beauty. I believe that at a fundamental level there is a reason for this. As John Keats says in “Ode on a Grecian Urn”, “Beauty is truth, truth beauty- That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.” Much of what we know in life is learned via education or experience. However, we seem to appreciate ethics and aesthetics, as Keats implies, without being taught in these expected ways. Both ethics and aesthetics are an attempt to describe rather then prescribe. Our studies of morality and beauty are, for the most part, attempts to explain why a piece of art or literature is beautiful, or why an action is moral, rather than a set of rules for judging, or creating, good art or moral behavior. 
	More to the point, criticism of art or morals is never able to fully capture the essence of what is good or what is beautiful. A conversation about the worth of da Vinci's Mona Lisa, for example, may center around concepts like foreground, background, contrast, or cultural context, but in the end, these do not describe why it is good art. Rather, when one is asked about a favorite work of art or literature it is common to hear a phrase similar to, “There's just something about it” preceding a more complex or critical explanation. I believe that both art and morals can never be completely reduced to a description of their qualities. As Flannery O'Connor says, “A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way . . . you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate.” No matter how completely we describe the properties of a work of literature, there is something transcendent which is still left. I believe that ethics has this same property. As Wittgenstein says, “It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. / Ethics is transcendental. / . I suggest that it is this “something”, this je ne sais quoi, which is art and morality's most powerful attribute, and that this transcendental nature of both ethics and aesthetics provides a connection point between them.
	I believe that morality and art are so closely related because we experience both of them most powerfully at a noumenally, to use a Kantian term. They impact us at a level that can be experienced, but not fully explained. This link is even stronger when it comes to the art of literature. As McKean says, “What most distinguishes literature from the other arts, what is, in truth, unique about the art, is its moral quality. It may be that moral standards are inappropriate to other arts, music, for instance, but they seem to be as relevant to literature as they are to life itself. Living necessarily involves values. . . . Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there” .

The Germany of today is considered a strong force, a united country with its own blend of culture from within the shadows of the alps in München, all the way to Baltic sea city of Kiel.  The same culture can be felt from Köln on the river Rhine, through the centre of Germany to the Saxon city of Dresden located on the Elbe. With such a unique culture, it shouldn't be surprising that Germany as we now know it comes from several different sources, and tribes. 

Germania is the ancestral land of the Germans. The origins of the name are highly disputed among scholars and historians. Tacitus claimed that the name came from a Germanic Tribe known then as Tungrians, and that they had previously been known as Germans before they crossed the Rhine and battled the Gaulish forces (Tacitus, 98.) Julius Caesar first used the word “Germanus” in his commentary on the Gallic Wars where he put down the Gauls and battled with Germanic tribes which crossed the Rhine often under mischievous premisses. He took this word from The Gauls themselves, and used it to distinguish between those which he had conquered (The Gauls) and those which he had not. While the origin is uncertain, some believe it referred to a neighbor in the Gaulish language. In the first chapter, of his first book on these wars, Julius Caesar notes: “Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles.” (Julius Caesar, 50-40 BC) Others claim the meaning comes from the spear that they used in warfare, known as a ger (O.E.D, 2010), or perhaps from the Old Irish word garim meaning “to shout”, which indicated the Germans were loud, or noisy. (Names of Germany) 

 The early Roman historian Tacitus recorded in his AD 98 writing “De Origine et situ Germanorum”, which told of the origins of the Germans, that “I should regard (The Germans) as aboriginal, and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse. For, in former times it was not by land but on shipboard that those who sought to emigrate would arrive.......Who would leave Asia, or Africa, for Italy for Germany, with its wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect, unless indeed it were his home?(SIC)” (Tacitus, 98) 

And who would leave Rome for Germania? Certainly not the Romans, not yet at least. They would send out their conquests into the lands of Germania for goods, and lead the occasional land campaign but in the end they mostly returned back home to their sprawling empire. So as the Germanic tribes began appearing in the middle of the first century, they lived on the borders of the Roman Empire and traded their goods taken from the land, and their skills by serving within the ranks of the Roman army, (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

The play Twelfth Night seems to say that although disguise is in fact useful in perpetrating long bouts of deception, in the end a person must reject that newly formed guise, or else risk losing themselves forever in the process. A big problem with ending a deception, however, is that one may find themselves alienated in the process. Therefore, in the end, one must decide between one’s own self preservation, or the preservation of relationships with those around them. For although some will respond neutrally to discovering that they’ve been tricked, still others will not take the deception so lightly, and will be likely be offended by the whole charade.
The topic of deception in gender role reversal is especially problematic, because it brings up many side issues, perhaps the most important one being, why? Why does the subject feel the need to shirk their own identity and take up a disguise in the form of the opposite gender? In Viola’s case, it is obviously a form of self protection.: “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” (5.1.247-249)
Having newly arrived in a foreign land, Viola feels it necessary to pretend to be a man to protect herself from would be attackers. Viola’s plan works, but it also alienates her from the women around her, cutting her off from an important support system. To make matters worse, she is apparently so convincing at appearing to be a man that Olivia confuses her with Sebastian, and in effect falls in love with her. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138) On top of that, she also has to deal with suppressed romantic desires between her and Orsino: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1. 260-261)
Although this may be a somewhat progressive attitude, to the modern reader, Twelfth Night may be seen as an illustration of how deception may help facilitate the unveiling of suppressed emotions, especially in the cases of Olivia and Orsino. Certain passages seem to hint that the aforesaid characters may have unexpressed subconscious desires that the appearance of Viola/Cesario forces them to deal with. For instance, is Olivia attracted to Cesario because Cesario appears to be a man, or does Olivia really secretly harbor feelings for women? One would argue that this is probably not the case, because Shakespeare’s character Olivia seems more likely to be parodying those people of his time period who judge others only upon their looks. 
This is evidenced by the ease with which Olivia switches her romantic ardors from Cesario to Sebastian, and begins to regard Cesario/Viola as family rather than a love interest: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315)

German colonial rule has been noted by various observers for its brutality, notably with respect to the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama in German South West Africa. Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

The United States of America and Mexico are an example of two nations which at one time were beset by an enduring rivalry which spanned 57 years, from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts 2000 p. 145).  The high-water mark of this rivalry was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, where the United States attacked and defeated Mexico and secured for itself Texas and the American Southwest as new territory.  Many other clashes happened between the two nations, finally abating just before the First World War.   The rivalry began as Americans and Mexicans clashed on key issues such as religion, culture and tradition and had a major clash of material interests (Schmitt 1974 p. 30-31).   
	This is not unlike many other nations who have an enduring rivalry with a neighbor.  Nations which share a border tend to have clashes of interests which lend to the creation of rival positions between the nations.  The United States and Mexico are not unlike many other enduring rivalries between nations which share a common border.  David M. Pletcher (1977) states that “Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems” (p. 41).  Indeed, both of these nations are geographically close to the United States and have been rivals to the United States, while other nations in Latin America enjoy and have enjoyed good relations with the United States.   
	Religious issues created a rift between the two nations, a problem which has beset many nations through history.  Sally Frahm (2001) states that ”if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy”  (p.86).  Not unlike the Cold War’s rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union was part ideological struggle and part a competition over interests each nation deemed vital. In this case, however, the ideological struggles weren’t based on the political structure but on instead the religious preferences of the United States and Mexico.  This distrust grew from the distrust between the English and Spanish.  Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
Culture aint no simple thing to pin down. It moves like smoke through the fingers of them that try to grasp it, defined more by its absence than its presence, like the shadow of a bird across the desert floor. They say you can mark a culture by its traits but that aint true neither. No more than you can mark a man by the color of his eyes or the way he holds his knife at supper.

The old ones who say all Russians is stubborn or all Japanese bend like reeds in the wind, they dont know. They aint never set across from them at a table with papers spread out like the bones of dead things, watching and waiting. A man who aims to deal with folk from other places best know how their ways shape the words they speak and the silences between them. When you walk in foreign lands you carry your own land with you like a mirror, showing you what's different and what's the same.

To know another peoples ways you got to study their dead and their living both. Their wars and their peace. Their gods and their devils. Aint no point in trying to change what time and blood have written. You got to work within the walls they built, specially when you come as a stranger to their gates with your hat in your hand. And if youre standing on their ground you best honor their ways lest you find yourself talking to empty chairs.

Them corporate folks got their own tribes too, each office tower like a different nation. Some wear their suits like armor and count their hours like misers count gold. Others let their people come and go like wild horses, so long as the work gets done. You can read their laws in the clothes they wear and the words they speak or dont speak. Even in one company the tribes differ, from city to prairie, from mountain to sea.

Values run deeper than a river in flood. If a man's people believe in keeping face like keeping breath, he aint gonna shame himself or his kin just to win some paper victory. And them that believe in fighting tooth and nail for every scrap, they aint gonna lay down their arms at the first sign of peace. Best know these things before you sit at their table. But knowing a man's culture aint the same as knowing the man. That's a different kind of knowledge altogether, earned one word and one silence at a time.

They say the fool speaks godlessness in his heart and these words echo through time from ancient psalms to the writings of the old saint Anselm and beyond. Dark words writ in darker times. And Aquinas too carried this torch through the medieval night though neither man could fully illuminate the vastness they sought to explain.

The God they pursued was not some nameless force moving through creation like wind through dead grass but the very God of scripture, terrible and magnificent. To speak of other gods would be to speak of nothing at all. Nothing at all.

Anselm walked the inward path. Said that God dwelt in understanding itself and that the very thought of God proved his existence like a fingerprint pressed into the clay of consciousness. As if the mind itself was testament enough. As if faith could birth certainty from the womb of doubt.

But Aquinas. He walked different ground. Believed that God could be found in the bones of the world itself, in the mechanism of change and cause, in the very architecture of being. Five paths he carved through the wilderness of reason. Each one leading to the same destination like trails converging at a mountain peak none had seen but all knew must exist.

He spoke of change and how it moved through all things like blood through veins, spoke of causes stretching back through time like links in an infinite chain, of contingency and excellence and the terrible harmony that bound all things together in their proper place. As if the universe itself was a vast puzzle with one piece removed, and in that absence was proof of presence.

But neither man's words could capture the whole of it. Like trying to catch sunlight in a jar or hold back the tide with your hands. Their arguments stood like weathered stones in an ancient field, marking something that was there but could never fully be measured or known.

Words carry weight and writers know this truth deep in their bones like ancient hunters knew the patterns of prey. They wield their tools like weapons, some sharper than others, some deadlier in their purpose. Fitzgerald, he knew these tools well. In that book of his, The Great Gatsby, he worked his craft with a precision that would make a surgeon weep. He'd take words that had no business being together and force them to dance, make them tell stories they weren't meant to tell. But it was in the colors where his real power lay, like some old medicine man mixing his paints. Gold and green and white and gray and that damned pink-red that bleeds through the pages like a wound that won't heal.

The white and gray, they speak of sameness, of the crushing weight of uniformity that presses down on all things. White for the rich folks with their starched collars and manufactured smiles, gray for the used-up and worn-down. They're everywhere in his pages, these colors, like ghosts that won't rest. Daisy and Jordan floating through scenes in their white dresses like pale phantoms. Nick in his white flannels, Tom in his white shirt, all of them wearing their whiteness like armor against the dark. Even Catherine, powdered white as death itself, like some carnival mask that can't hide what's beneath.

The city rises up in white canyons, vast and empty as bleached bones in the desert sun. The names of party-goers fade to gray like old newspapers left in the rain. Apartment buildings stack up like slices of some monstrous white cake that no one wants to eat. The whole world turned to white and gray, like God himself ran out of colors and had to make do.

And then there's Daisy, poor doomed Daisy in her white dress and white car, moving through the story like a ghost that doesn't know it's dead. Fitzgerald paints her with these colors deliberate-like, showing us what she really is - just another piece in the great machine of sameness, something for Gatsby to chase after like a man chasing his own shadow. She wears that gray fur collar like a noose, and when she appears again in white before the final showdown, it's like watching a funeral procession where the corpse doesn't know it's supposed to lie down.

The land lay golden and quiet beneath the California sun, stretching out across San Diego County like some ancient promise made flesh. Here the soil yielded its bounty year after year, the earth giving forth tomatoes and citrus and greens in endless procession, while squash grew fat and yellow in their beds and broccoli stood like tiny forests in perfect rows. The trees bore peaches and lemons and the bees made their honey and all manner of pepper grew red and angry in the endless summer light.

They called it organic farming now, though it was just farming as it had always been before the world grew modern and cruel. People waited in long lines to claim their share of eggs still warm from the hen and milk pure as scripture. The farmers opened their gates to the townfolk who came to walk the land and watch the birds wheel overhead in their ancient patterns, as if nothing in the world had changed since time began.

The land itself was one hundred and sixty acres that pressed against the Cleveland National Forest like a supplicant. Chaparral and grassland brought over by long-dead settlers from across the sea, and oak woodland that had stood sentinel since before any man walked these hills. Here lived creatures whose names read like a litany of the dying: the kangaroo rat and the yellow-legged frog and the gnatcatcher, all of them fading like old photographs in the merciless march of progress.

The Indians had walked here first, their footsteps lost to time, and after them came the ranchers with their cattle and the woodcutters with their saws, all of them taking what they could from the land until nothing remained but dust and memory. The earth remembered though, in the way that all things remember their wounds, and now men sought to heal it with their careful tending and their programs and their papers filled with promises.

But the land cared nothing for promises. It demanded sweat and blood and endless labor, the breaking of backs and the callousing of hands. Without the poisons that other men used, the farmer must wage constant war against weed and pest, must nurse the soil like a sick child, must accept that some battles would be lost to nature's indifferent eye. Yet still they came, these new farmers, armed with hope and government grants, seeking to make peace with the land their forebears had wronged.

The bond between brothers runs deep as blood and ancient as stone. It moves like a river carrying all manner of things: love and pride and jealousy and cruelty floating like dead leaves on the water. Brothers know each other in ways that others cant know. They see themselves in each other like mirrors in a dark room. When the world turns black as pitch and hope dies that bond shows its true nature whether it be good or evil and there aint no going back from what gets revealed.

The price is always high. Always was and always will be. Understanding what flows between brothers means carrying the weight of what comes after. When you look into your brothers eyes and see yourself staring back you dont see what others see. You see the truth of what you are. Raw and real as hunger. Your deeds and their aftermath show what manner of creature you truly are.

In The Scarlet Ibis two brothers walk this path like so many before them. Through swamps thick with cypress and spanish moss where the air hangs heavy as wet wool they make their way on a fools errand. Pride crashes against disappointment like thunder against the hills and when the storm passes only one brother draws breath. We see it all through the eyes of the older brother who carries his own darkness. His view of the world around him black as pitch and twice as thick shapes everything he does.

Pride sits in his heart like a poison. From the first time he takes his crippled brother Doodle out into the world to their last terrible journey together he carries that poison inside him. He wanted a brother to teach the things he knew. To hold his breath underwater. To run. To climb the vines in Old Woman Swamp. He wanted someone to race to Horsehead Landing and sit with him in the highest branches of the pine behind the barn. But Doodle with his weak heart wasnt meant for such things. The doctors said he might not even live and if he did hed never be strong enough for what his brother dreamed. The older boy even thought about smothering Doodle with a pillow like you might do to some suffering animal. But when that small broken thing smiled at him something in his heart cracked open and let the light in. Even if just for a moment.

The mind of man aint nothing simple. It sits in the skull like some terrible engine, processing the world through meat and electricity and time. Men once thought it soft like wax or flat like paper or bound like some holy book but now they name it computer and processor and machine. These words too shall pass like wind through autumn trees, leaving only half-truths in their wake.

The world comes at us raw and violent. Light and sound and heat, all of it transformed by organs older than language into signals that race through the darkness behind our eyes. These signals pass through layers of knowing like water through stone, each layer writing its own truth upon them. When a man looks upon a black box against white, his mind builds it piece by piece like a carpenter. First the edges, sharp as obsidian against the pale. Then the shape emerges from darkness, but the mind already knows what it seeks. It hunts for boxes in the void, finding them before they fully form.

Attention sits like a gatekeeper at the crossroads of thought, deciding what passes and what dies in the dark. The grass beneath your boots contains multitudes, but the mind lets them fade like morning mist. Yet your name spoken across a crowded room cuts through the chaos like a knife. The mind decides what matters and what don't, and it decides again and again until the deciding becomes truth.

Memory is a graveyard of moments. Some fresh as morning dew, others buried deep in the loam of years. The mind takes words and makes them ghosts - sometimes as shapes on paper, sometimes as echoes in the skull, sometimes as meaning stripped bare of all else. They say working memory is like electricity dancing through meat, a brief carnival of light lasting twenty seconds before the darkness returns. Long-term memories hide in the very substance of us, in proteins twisted like barbed wire around the truth.

Men who study such things have drawn maps of knowledge like old explorers mapping terra incognita. They speak of networks of meaning, where chair begets table begets wood begets tree, all connected like veins in the body of knowing. But these are just maps, and the territory they describe remains wild and unknowable as the desert night.

They called it a crisis but that word was too clean for what came. In the year of our Lord 2007 the great machine of American prosperity shuddered and broke and left in its wake a darkness that stretched from sea to shining sea. Men who had built empires of paper watched them burn. The unemployed walked the streets like ghosts. Houses stood empty, their windows dark eyes staring at nothing.

The seeds of this devastation had been planted in years prior, when men in suits whose souls had long since been traded for power decided that everyone should own a piece of the American dream, whether they could afford it or not. Banks became merchants of false hope, dealing in loans that were poison, packaging them like bright candies and selling them to the unwitting. Fannie Mae and her twisted sister Freddie Mac danced to this tune of destruction, weaving spells of financial alchemy that turned lead into gold until the day the magic failed.

It began in the time of Clinton, that silver-tongued president who sought to extend his reign by making the people love him. In those days a man named Holmes spoke prophecy in the pages of the Times, warning of the darkness to come, but prophets are rarely heeded in their own time. The banks grew fat on the meat of bad debt, gorging themselves on the dreams of the poor and the desperate.

They built their tower of babel with strange words and stranger mathematics. Adjustable-rate mortgages. Collateralized debt obligations. Words that meant nothing and everything. The people leveraged their souls against houses they couldn't afford, and the banks leveraged their souls against the souls of the people, until the whole cursed edifice stood balanced on a knife's edge.

When it fell, it fell hard. The great houses of money - Bear Stearns, Merrill Lynch, Lehman Brothers - they fell like kings before the revolution. Four trillion in debt, a number so vast it loses all meaning. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley survived but were changed, transformed into something lesser, something mortal. And Fannie and Freddie, those twin architects of doom, fell into the arms of the government like condemned men into the arms of their executioner.

The words lay there like bones bleached in desert sun. Exposition. A word that writers clutch to their breast like some holy talisman though it carries death in its teeth. They string these words together like rotting prayer beads thinking they might save their souls but there aint no salvation in mere telling.

The monitor glows pale and blue in the dark room and Dr Merlin screams at it. Not the good kind of screaming neither. Just the raw animal sound of someone who's read too many words that dont do nothing except take up space on the page. Words that dont work. Words that dont bleed.

Show dont tell. That's what they say. Always been that way since stories first got told round fires in caves. But the devil he sits there on your shoulder whispering sweet poison. Tell em everything he says. Tell em bout the childhood and the dreams and the breakfast they ate. Tell em bout the gas station manager who once flew planes in wars he cant forget and who goes fishing on weekends to forget the wives who left him. Tell em everything and tell em nothing that matters.

Truth is you got to put meat on them bones. Got to make the reader feel the knife when it goes in. When that husband dies in front of his wife you got to make em taste the copper of his blood in their own mouths. Got to make em hear his last breath rattling out like wind through dead leaves. Otherwise its just words. Just marks on a page that dont signify nothing except the writer's own failure to make the reader care.

Exposition aint your friend. Never was. Never will be. Its just the easy way out and there aint nothing worth having that comes easy in this world.

The morning came cold and gray and the news flickered across the screen like phantoms in the dark. First came word of Ashley where a man had done violence upon his wife with a blade. Hostettler they called him and his face stared out from the screen with eyes black as pitch and hollow as drought-dead wells. The story passed quick as summer rain.

Then came word of the boy Travis. Eighteen summers had passed over him before the bullets found him in Sharon Woods. No harbinger of who had done this thing. SWAT men moved through the streets like armored beetles but found nothing. The story died quiet and quick like stories of his kind always do in this world. White faces linger longer on the screen. White tears fall heavier. That's the way of it.

The helicopter story came next. Some fool with a twentytwo had put a hole in a flying machine meant for mercy. Five thousand dollars for the shooter's name. The money hung in the air like carrion birds circling.

Weather came and went. Rain coming. Thunder too. Numbers that meant heat and time but signified nothing.

Then the UDF robbery. They spoke of the thief's darkness like it was a sin itself. Six foot tall they said. One fifty. Wearing cotton pulled over his head like a shroud. The words fell heavy with meaning that wasnt about the crime at all.

Last came the tale of Rodriguez. Drug lord they called him. Three hundred months they gave him though they meant twentyfive years. The numbers rolled strange off their tongues like they were speaking in tongues. They marked him Hispanic like marking cattle though it meant nothing to the weight of his crimes. The news ended and the screen went dark and somewhere in the distance a siren wailed.

They call it an ETF and it moves like a shadow across the financial plains, tracking indices and commodities and baskets of worth like some spectral thing that cannot be held but can be traded like common stock. It gives a man what they call diversification, same as any index fund might, but it carries with it the flexibility of a single share - the ability to sell short or buy on margin or purchase but one lonely share in the vast darkness of the market. The benefits lay there like gold coins in the dust but the costs, they run lower than what you'd pay them mutual fund men. There are drawbacks though. Always drawbacks in this world. You'll pay commission on every trade like you would with stock, no way around that truth.

The variety of these funds stretches out endless as the desert horizon but a man must look careful at what they promise. Diversification they say. Benefits they claim. But the wise investor, he must put these promises to the test like a prospector testing fool's gold against the real thing. We aim to examine one such creature called IHF, compare it against its ten biggest holdings like comparing a wolf to its teeth, see if owning the ETF brings the same bounty as owning them ten stocks separate, or if there might be some better way to arrange these same pieces.

The task of examining every holding would be like counting every grain of sand in the Mojave, so we took just the top ten, accounting for 63.58 percent of what's in there. They lay listed out like the names of the dead.

To reckon how true these ten stocks stand for the whole of IHF, we took their percentages and normalized them to a hundred, calculated what each one brings to the portfolio's Beta and Return if you was to build it just from these ten in the same proportions as the ETF holds them. The numbers stand stark in the chart below like cattle bones bleaching in the sun.

The figures tell a tale plain as day - a portfolio of just them top holdings runs 6.11 percent higher than the ETF itself, like a horse outrunning its shadow by sixteen percent. The Beta runs lower too, by point twelve. These numbers whisper that maybe them ten holdings alone might bring more reward with less risk. But numbers can lie like men can lie, and we needed to know if these differences were real as blood or just tricks of the light.

The numbers fell like winter birds shot from the sky, there in the third month. You could see it plain in Figure 17, the way the logs dwindled and died. No man could say why for certain though theories stalked the margins of understanding like hungry wolves. Winter had come as it always did to New England, merciless and raw, driving the bicycle riders and walkers from the roads. December too brought its own peculiar madness - the rush of endings, of grades to be counted like cattle bones, of work piled high like cordwood before the storm. The commuter logs became ghosts, forgotten things.

The holiday season descended like a shroud. Campus emptied, halls echoing with absence, parking lots barren as dead lakes. When January crawled back with its ice-teeth and iron sky, bringing students and teachers alike, the numbers stayed low, huddled against the cold. February offered no answers, just silence and snow.

Some said it was natural, the way all things burn bright then fade. Like a fire dying to embers. We fought back with what weapons we had - the Carpool Challenge Week in March, a desperate rally against the darkness. It worked some. The logs rose like smoke signals but the truth remained: the academic calendar was a beast that devoured momentum, swallowing whole months in its endless cycle of beginnings and endings.

But there was something deeper, something carved into the bone of American life itself. The car was freedom. Independence. A metal horse for the modern age. You could see it in their eyes when they gripped their steering wheels - that wild thing that wouldn't be tamed by coffee shop gift cards or restaurant vouchers. We gave these prizes like Indians trading beads, thinking they meant something. Maybe if we'd offered bigger game - sleek bicycles or those hybrid cars with their quiet engines, or even one of them electric vehicles that hummed like summer insects - maybe then we'd have seen different numbers in those cold months. Could have announced it like prophets: December bringing bicycles, January bringing hybrid chariots. Might have kept them believing, kept them logging their miles like pilgrims counting rosary beads. But we'll never know. Some questions don't have answers, just theories that circle like crows over a battlefield.

I set to wandering through the old Edison reels laid up in the Library of Congress like ancient scrolls in some forbidden archive. Fifteen of them there were, dating from 1895 to 1901, each one a trick film meant to deceive the eye and mind both. They were crafted in ways that would make a man question what was real and what wasnt real and perhaps if there was any difference between the two at all.

The films stood like sentinels against time itself. Bound to their sets like prisoners to stakes, they peered out through a proscenium arch that knew neither movement nor mercy. The camera stood fixed and distant as God himself, watching through long shots and medium shots but never daring closer, as if some unwritten commandment had been laid down in the early days of moving pictures.

In those flickering images you could see the ghost of vaudeville haunting every frame. The players moved like marionettes on invisible strings, sliding sideways across the stage as if afraid to approach the eye that watched them. Take that peculiar piece they called Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel, made in 1900. Josh and his fellow specters dance their sideways waltz, entering stage right like souls crossing the River Styx, but never advancing toward that glass eye that captured their movements for all time.

The rules of this new world were strict and unforgiving as desert law. One shot was one film, no more and no less, though sometimes the magicians behind the lens would splice their celluloid together in secret ways to make spirits appear and vanish like smoke. These tales rarely stretched beyond a minute's length, brief as life itself sometimes seems, and simpler than the stories told round campfires since time began.

Watch close The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots from 1895 and you might catch the sleight of hand where they switched the living queen for her manufactured double. The trick is there plain as day if you know where to look, like the truth hiding in plain sight. But in those days folks weren't looking for truth in moving pictures. They were looking for magic, and magic they found in those strange mechanical dreams projected on white sheets in darkened rooms.

The Gothic Novel stands as both ancient and new, a contradiction bleeding through time like a wound that won't heal. Some call it hollow, others praise its terrible beauty, but truth dont care much for what men call things. Horace Walpole, he took what was old and what was new and stitched them together like some nightmarish creature, breathing life into what we now call Gothic. The Castle of Otranto it was called. A Gothic Story, he named it, simple as that.

Medieval ghosts dance through these pages, stone walls and ancient rites rising up like dead things from the earth. Gothic they called it then, Gothic they call it now, though the word means different things to different men in different times. Some saw it as primitive, backward even, standing against the march of progress like a stubborn mule. But the marriage of theatrical Gothic ways with the intimacy of novel writing, that union survived, transformed, became something else entirely. Something that could speak to souls across centuries.

Chivalry runs through it all like blood through veins. The medieval knight, that ancient ideal of honor and courage, haunts these pages like a restless spirit. Walpole saw something missing in his time, something lost that needed finding again. The world he knew was sick with politics and lies, and maybe he thought the old ways, the gothic ways, held some cure for what ailed society. You can see it clear as day in characters like Frederic, who stands like some fever dream of what a knight should be.

They wrote him as suffering nobility, a prince who'd walked through fire and come out changed. Said he'd been killed by infidels, though dead men dont usually walk back into stories. The gallant and courteous Knight, they called him, though even then the description dripped with excess like honey from a broken comb, sweet but somehow wrong.

The chain moves like blood through veins, goods passing raw and unformed through the stages of their becoming until they reach the hands that called for them. Oliver had named it in '82, this dark procession of material and want, though the thing itself was ancient as commerce and trade and the first bartering of shells for meat. He'd written of it in terms clinical and stark, speaking of implementation and control and satisfaction but the truth of it lay deeper, in the bone-knowledge of need and the fulfilling of it.

Six pillars hold up this temple of commerce. Production. Supply. Inventory. Location. Transportation. Information. The managers move between these pillars like priests of some mercantile faith, conducting their rituals of efficiency and service.

Production stands first among these, a cornerstone on which all else rests. It begins with knowing, with reading the auguries of the market like ancient seers reading entrails, seeking in the patterns of purchase and desire what must be brought forth into the world. The managers peer into these depths and from them draw forth numbers, quantities, locations. They choose their grounds like generals planning campaigns, selecting which fortress of industry will birth which goods, measuring volume against quality against the endless hunger of demand.

They map the work in ledgers and computer screens, scheduling the labors like the movements of armies. Each detail matters, each minute particular bearing the weight of consequence. A misstep here cascades through the chain like poison in a river. He'd seen it himself in the great retail houses, Walmart and Target, where every action from the folding of a shirt to the receiving of a truck followed patterns laid down like scripture in their manuals and guides.

Supply comes next, the choosing of capabilities and alliances. Like a general dividing his forces, management must decide which battles each division will fight, what specialties each will claim. Sometimes they send work out beyond their walls, seeking velocity - that holy grail of quality and flexibility won at the altar of reduced cost.

They came in their volumes from that old time, those books bound in leather and gilt, speaking of drawing rooms and tea services and the finery of men who wore topcoats and carried silver-headed canes. But there were others. Dark things. Books that crawled with nightmares and the blackness that dwells in men's souls. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights stood apart, wrought in shadow and bearing witness to mysteries that lay beneath the surface of proper society like corpses in shallow graves.

In them the darkness speaks. Dreams come unbidden and terrible. In Oliver's tale the boy walks between Sikes and Crackit, phantoms made real in his fever-addled mind, their voices echoing as if across vast canyons of time. Gunfire splits the night. Screams pierce the darkness. Lights dance like witchfire before his eyes while pain, constant as original sin, gnaws at his bones. Some hand, unseen and perhaps guided by providence or perhaps by darker forces, bears him away through this carnival of horrors.

The dreams speak truth in these tales. In Oliver's story they reveal the rotting underneath, the helplessness of a child cast adrift in a world of wolves. When the shooting comes again in chapter twenty-eight it comes like judgment, like prophecy fulfilled. The boy relives it all, trapped in that moment between life and death while Sikes and Crackit hover over him like carrion birds. The pain is everywhere and nowhere, diffuse as morning fog, married now to fear rather than shock. Oliver drifts, powerless as a leaf in a river. Whatever will drove the bullet into his flesh, it was not his own. Here Fagin's poison has done its work, breaking something essential in the boy's soul, leaving him adrift in a world without mercy or meaning.

Time itself bends and breaks. Day becomes night becomes day, all meaning lost in the terrible silence of darkness, in the fleeting hours that pass like shadows across the face of a dying moon.

Years back I worked with the young ones after their schooling was done for the day. Helping them with their studies and whatever troubles they had with their learning. English and reading being what I knew best. There was this boy Adrian, third or fourth grade he must have been, brought to me by one of the teachers on account of his troubles with reading. Something wasnt right with the way he read. Letters that should have come natural to him were foreign things and others he knew like old friends. He was Latino sure enough but spoke English clear as any native born child. We went on like that for a time until I saw his mother. 

I was watching some stragglers while the others had gone off somewhere when she came in. Not a word of English passed her lips. Just Spanish. My own Spanish being poor we managed somehow but that's when it hit me like judgment day. Adrian could read well enough but the English letters were strange creatures to him, different from what he knew at home.

This here is about the wall between languages in our schools, particularly in California where I am. Sometimes the wall aint as clear as we might think. Even children who speak English proper can find themselves lost in the reading of it like wanderers in some foreign land. We all know this truth but what's to be done about it. For Adrian the answer was simple enough. Show him the letters, teach him their sounds. But for those who barely know English at all the answer aint so clear.

Theres no single path through this wilderness. Two-language teaching, throwing them in with English speakers, private teaching, special English classes. None of these alone will do what needs doing. The answer lies in using them all together like a man needs both horse and saddle to ride. The two-language way of teaching aint just good for Spanish speakers but for all of them. Studies show these children do better than their peers though many fear it's a waste. If we made this the way of things instead of just sometimes doing it all would be better for it. We dont need every teacher speaking two tongues. That aint realistic. But having helpers who know both languages, that's something we can do sure enough.

From youth we are told of something greater than ourselves. A thing vast and unknowable that dwells beyond the veil of comprehension. Some seek it in wooden pews and stained glass temples while others quest inward through the dark corridors of self. Many accept without question the ancient stories passed down like worn copper coins from parent to child. Others rage against these inheritances, these tales told in the night, proclaiming themselves sole arbiters of their universe. All of us wanderers in the dark, searching for that pale fire that might lead us from shadow into light.

The old man said cardinal and nothing more. We sat watching the rain beat against the tin roof, cigarette smoke rising like spectral fingers into the wet air. Water rushed through the gutters and drowned the flowers that grew wild at the porch edge. His eyes fixed on some distant point where memory and rain became one thing. His clothes hung from him like a scarecrow's rags, his hair thin as corn silk. Neither of us spoke of what was coming. What words could stand against such darkness? I moved my chair closer to his and together we watched the rain fall through the June twilight like tears from an indifferent god.

He died in December. Five days after I turned twenty-two. The medicines they gave him did nothing but stretch his suffering like a wire pulled taut, vibrating with pain. I cursed whatever god might exist in that vast darkness. No prayers passed my lips in those long nights. If there was something out there listening it had turned away long ago, deaf to the suffering of men.

I could not watch him die. Would not. The act of witnessing seemed a betrayal of all he had been in life. I knew him better than any of them. Knew he would not want his child to stand vigil at his ending. For three days I lay curled in my bed like some wounded animal, waiting for word of his passing.

No word came.

The man Taylor of Caroline carried the flame of Republicanism in his heart like a torch in darkness. He worked the land with his hands and knew its ways, and from this knowing came his thoughts on freedom and the workings of men who would govern others. The soil was his teacher and his prophet both, and from it sprang forth all manner of opinion on how men should live and be ruled and what constituted right in this world.

He saw in this new country a thing that had never been, pristine and untouched by the old ways that plagued the minds of men across the water. Here lay virgin ground for self-governance, unsullied by ancient custom. The rights of man, he knew, were like links in an iron chain. Break one and the whole would fail, becoming nothing more than scattered metal in the dust. These rights stood beyond the reach of any government, sacred and inviolate.

Taylor knew the darkness that dwelled in men's hearts. He saw how in nature the strong preyed upon the weak and how the clever-cruel prospered while the righteous suffered. But civilization, he reckoned, must stand against such base inclinations.

The good and the evil in man existed like two wolves in the same woods, and Taylor believed any government worth its salt must account for both. Good principles protected what a man owned, made the earth yield its bounty, and kept the moneylenders at bay. But even the finest government would draw the greedy and the power-hungry like carrion birds to flesh. Self-interest, that eternal force, moved through all men like blood through veins. Only when it turned parasitic, feeding off the labor of others, did it become a thing of evil.

Taylor stood with those who held the Constitution as writ, not to be bent or twisted by clever men with sharp tongues. The federal beast, he knew, must be kept small and lean, lest it grow fat on the wealth of the people and turn tyrannical in its appetites. But words alone were not enough - the spirit of the law's makers must be remembered, like an old testament passed down through generations. And above all else stood the Declaration, that sacred scroll that spoke of sovereign states bound together not in bondage but in common cause.

He stood and looked down and in looking down he saw what lay there before him and what lay there was nothing he had asked for nor wanted nor sought. The mind worked at it like some machine grinding slow and methodical and mechanical in its purpose yet serving no greater end than the watching itself. Thoughts came and went like wraiths in the desert wind leaving no trace of their passing.

He remembered the artist and the book she'd told him to buy. Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain it was called and in it lay all manner of instruction from the basic handling of pencil to the way the mind sees what it sees and makes of it what it will. The book spoke of frames and boundaries and how they could take the vast terrible wholeness of a thing and reduce it to something a man might comprehend. A kitchen becoming just a table becoming just a bowl of fruit sitting there patient and indifferent to the eye that beheld it.

But there was no frame for this. No boundary to contain what lay before him in the porcelain bowl. Like some primitive artist working in shades of brown and waste and human leavings he stood sentinel over his unwanted canvas. Picasso had his blues and Monet his greens but this was different. This was base and real and wouldn't be contained by any artist's vision.

His fingers found the handle and in finding it gave purpose to the moment. Water rushed and swirled carrying bits and pieces to nowhere but the mass remained. Unmoved. Uncaring. He flushed again with greater urgency but still it stayed, affixed to the bowl like some prehistoric creature frozen in amber.

He stood in his uniform, the green tie at his throat like a noose, feet planted wide on the tile floor of the Rite Aid bathroom. The toilet paper came away in sheets and he wrapped his hand in it like a man preparing for some grim surgery. Then bending at the waist he reached down into those cold waters like a man reaching into the bowels of the earth itself...

They die on the roads these children. Die in twisted metal and shattered glass while the night stretches endless before them. The government men in their white coats say the young brain aint ready for such things. Not ready for the violence of speed and momentum and physics that care nothing for youth or dreams or promises made.

Inexperience stalks them like a predator in the dark. Rolls their machines like toys. Sends them careening off into ditches where they lay burning or bleeding or both. And they travel in packs these young ones. Always in packs. The way of their kind since time was time. Studies done in California show the truth of it. The more of them packed together the more of them die.

The state tries to control it with paper laws and curfews but these are just words written in ink that wash away in blood. Even at eighteen the hunger for danger lives in their bones like a parasite. Some doctor named Zuckerman he studied it. Wrote about how they chase the thrill of it like addicts chase the needle. And now more are coming. Children of the boomers. Millions of them. Ready to take the wheel.

They talk about fixing it. About schools teaching them and permits that say when they can drive and when they cant. Like you can control death with bureaucracy. Make it wait its turn. They want national laws now. As if the reaper cares about state lines. As if metal and momentum recognize borders drawn by men in offices far away.

None of this is new. The road has always taken its toll and always will. The young have always died on it and always will. That's the nature of speed and steel and youth. The nature of a world that don't care how many summers you've seen or how many you thought you had left to see.

They called it Central Auditory Processing Disorder though the name meant little to those afflicted. A darkness in the mind where sounds go to die or become twisted things unrecognizable from their original form. Not deafness no. The ears work as God intended but somewhere in the labyrinth of gray matter the meaning gets lost like a traveler in some vast desert with no landmarks to guide him home.

The disorder existed before men put a name to it. In the middle of the last century they began to study it. Italian doctors with names like prayers - Bocca, Calearo, Cassinari. They developed their tests and their methods while across the ocean Kimura worked on his own solutions like some medieval alchemist searching for gold in lead. In seventy-seven they gathered, these seekers of truth, to share what little they knew of this thing that lived in the minds of children.

The manifestations came like specters in the night. A man might hear perfectly well yet be unable to tell where the sound originated as if the world itself had become unmoored from direction and space. Words might blur together like watercolors in rain. Patterns of sound that made sense to others became meaningless rhythms without form or substance. The subtle shifts in human speech that carry meaning beyond the words themselves - these too could be lost leaving only hollow shells of communication behind.

They tested for it in sterile rooms with machines that measured the invisible. Audiologists psychologists speech pathologists all with their instruments and questionnaires seeking answers in the darkness of the human mind. No single test could reveal its presence with certainty. Like tracking some mythical beast they followed its spoor through the forest of human consciousness looking for signs and markers that might betray its presence. They presented sounds in pairs and groups watching how the mind failed to separate them like a prospector sifting through river mud for precious metals that might or might not exist.

They were all of them broken things. That's what I'd seen. Souls fractured and scattered like shattered glass on concrete, glinting dangerous in the sun. I knew then what I must do. The path ahead lay clear as bones bleached white in desert sand. Social work. To wade into the darkness where children huddle against walls and families eat themselves alive with poison words and harder things.

The values rode with me like old companions. Service. Respect. Ethics raw and pure as winter wind. Commitment to mend what's torn between people and to keep my own blade sharp for the work ahead. These weren't just words written in some college manual. They were blood truth.

I wandered long years uncertain, watching folks try to outrun their demons. Some found the bottle. Others found worse things. I studied psychology then, trying to understand the machinery of hurt. But understanding ain't enough. Never was.

The boy came in summer. Sixteen and scared, perched on my friend's couch like a wounded bird. His parents had done things. Bad things. Dark things that leave marks deeper than skin. I went to their house next day after he called the law. Told the police my credentials, such as they were. They let me talk to the parents. Watched them squirm and lie, calling their boy manipulative, calling violence simple disputes. That's when I knew. Knew what I had to become.

Justice is a strange thing in this world. We talk about individuals like they're precious gold but try to stamp them all the same shape. I never did take to that. Colored my hair wild as desert flowers, marked my flesh with metal, stood with the outcasts and the different ones. Fought against the darkness of racism and hate wherever it showed its teeth. Some folks call that rebellion. I call it truth.

The road ahead is dark and full of thorns, but I'll walk it anyway. Because somewhere out there children are crying in the night, and somebody's got to answer.

Sleep and its disorders lay before us like ancient riddles writ in the flesh of man. They come in forms both primary and secondary, though such distinctions matter little to those who walk the midnight hours seeking rest that will not come. There are those who study these afflictions, cataloging them in neat rows like bones in an archaeologist's tent, sorting them into categories they call Dyssomnias and Parasomnias, words that taste of dust and academia.

The sleepless ones. They carry their burden like a cross, dragging it through days that blur into nights that refuse to yield their peace. Primary Insomnia they call it, when sleep becomes a stranger for thirty nights or more. Its dark brother, Hypersomnia, drags its victims down into endless drowning sleep, while Narcolepsy strikes like a rattler, sudden and without mercy.

Deep in the hypothalamus, in the terrible machinery of the brain, neurons fire their ancient signals. They speak in tongues of orexin, these messengers of wake and sleep. The scientists, they took their mice and watched these neurons dance. GABAB receptors, they said, like gatekeepers at the edge of consciousness. When they forced these gates open with their chemicals - baclofen they called it - sleep came like a flood. The mice slept, and in their sleep they carried secrets about our own darkness.

But the truth of sleep lies deeper than receptors and neurons. It runs in bloodlines, passes from father to son like eye color or the shape of hands. When these inherited gates are broken, sleep becomes a ghost, haunting but never touching, and the sleepless ones must drag themselves through their days like wounded animals. They sit in fluorescent-lit offices, stand at assembly lines, drive their children to school, all while carrying the weight of endless waking, their eyes burning like coals in the desert of consciousness.

He'd been there two and a half years or thereabouts, counting time in semesters like notches on a gun. The campus stretched vast and unforgiving before him, a concrete wilderness where souls wandered lost between buildings old as sin and new as tomorrow's promise. That first year they'd put him in East Halls, far out on the eastern edge where civilization gave way to the stadium's hulking shadow. The walk from Stuart Hall to Willard was a pilgrimage of sorts, twenty-five minutes through whatever hell the Pennsylvania weather chose to unleash, and it was always choosing.

An old graduate, not much older than himself but carrying the wisdom of years past, spoke of times when East Halls stood alone in a sea of empty land, like an island of brick and mortar in an ocean of nothing. Now that emptiness had been filled with the bones of progress - sports fields and buildings rising like monoliths from the earth, the Creamery and health services among them, apartment complexes circling like vultures on the periphery. The campus grew like a living thing, devouring space, making distance an enemy to be conquered.

The bicycle came as salvation. Not just the machine itself but the idea of it, the promise of freedom in two wheels and a chain. He'd heard tell of a friend who'd returned to cycling after years away, speaking of it like a man who'd found religion again. Bikes are great, the friend had said, the words carrying the weight of prophecy. For a time they weren't cool but they were always right, always true.

He lived off campus now, far as any dormitory, maybe farther. The bicycle had been an investment in survival. Thomas building loomed twenty-five minutes distant by foot, but the bike cut through time like a blade, reducing the journey to five minutes of pure velocity. Pollock Road lay between, a straight shot but treacherous, populated by wandering souls and metal beasts. Walking was for those with time to burn, and time was a currency he couldn't spare. Each day without the bike would cost him forty minutes, time multiplied across days and weeks until it became a burden too heavy to bear.

They came for the machines and the money both. In the pages of his testament Huxley had seen it coming like a storm rolling across the plains of human consciousness, dark and vast and terrible. The people in his vision stood as cattle in their pens, branded with letters that marked their worth, their minds scrubbed clean of individual thought by the relentless whispers in the night. They called it conditioning. A word clean as bleached bone but beneath it lay something darker.

The World Controller stood above them all like some pagan god of old, dispensing happiness like communion wafers, hollow and tasteless but necessary all the same. Through the lens of Marx's prophecies you could see the truth of it, written in the blood of human autonomy. Words like homogeny and reification rattled like dead men's teeth in the skull of progress.

The false consciousness lay upon them like a burial shroud. The lower orders - Deltas, Gammas, all of them marked and numbered like livestock - moved through their days in a soma-induced haze, buying and spending and rutting with mechanical precision. They knew nothing of their chains. The Alphas and Betas watched from their towers of privilege, knowing but not speaking, seeing but not acting. Bernard alone stood witness, though his testimony fell on ears stopped with cotton and comfort.

There was no love in this brave new world. The characters moved through their assigned roles like marionettes, strings pulled by unseen hands. The men spoke of women as if describing machinery - pneumatic, functional, interchangeable parts in the great engine of society. The women catalogued their couplings like accountants tallying figures in a ledger. Each caste accepted their place with the quiet resignation of the damned, consuming their allotted pleasures, obeying their prescribed commandments, walking in lockstep toward some horizon they could neither see nor understand.

Four years back I sat in a room where they spoke of Islam. The walls were white and clean like bones bleached in the desert sun. Men and women argued whether this faith carried violence in its heart. The question echoes still, louder now than before, like thunder rolling across empty plains.

Since the towers fell I watched how the papers and screens changed their tune. First with venom and spite then with a sweetness that seemed false as a serpent's smile. Strange days these are when a man named Barack Obama, carrying Muslim blood in his veins, could reach for the highest seat in this land.

The Prophet's tale sits heavy in my hands. Words that dont match the blood-soaked history I know. They tell of a gentle man but history whispers different truths. In the old stories he rode with sword and flame, making converts of the conquered. Yet here in these pages he walks humble and meek, waiting for men to find truth in his words like water in the desert.

The writers laid their words careful as trappers setting snares. They painted miracles that mirror the Christ's own works. Mutton and milk multiplied like loaves and fishes. A mockery. They stole the holy stories and dressed them in different clothes, thinking none would notice the theft.

They built their truth on whispers. One man telling another who told another still, like wind carrying dust across empty places. Each story passed through many mouths before finding paper, and truth has a way of changing shape when it travels so far.

What burns worst is how they made him holy. Gentle. Wise. But history carries darker truths, written in blood and steel. I wonder if the faithful know what darkness sleeps in their prophet's past, what violence birthed their faith. Some truths are better left in shadow, but they have a way of finding light.

They cast off his teachings like old clothes. Left them there in the dust of time while the world spun on and men spoke of things they knew nothing about. The truth of it was simple enough. Christianity had wandered far from where it began, like some nomadic tribe lost in the wasteland, each generation straying further from the path until they forgot there ever was one.

Now the world turns different. Progressive they call it. The old ones still cling to their ways like driftwood in a flood but their numbers grow thin and their voices grow weak. There's a awakening coming. Like thunder rolling across the plains. People wanting to strip away the layers of doctrine built up like rust on iron, wanting to find what lies beneath. Might take years. Might take centuries. Don't matter none. It'll come just the same.

They'll peel back time like the skin of some ancient fruit. Layer by layer. Until there ain't nothing left but what he said. What he meant. Before the others came with their own ideas about what God wanted. When it comes it'll sweep through like wildfire. Through the cities and the towns. Through the old world and the new. The church'll still stand but it'll be different. Like a house stripped down to its bones.

Where there was many there'll be one. Where there was difference there'll be sameness. It's happened before. Rome hunted Christians like wolves then bent its knee to the cross. Black men went from chains to power. The wheel turns and what was down comes up and up comes down.

They'll read his words different too. Not like reading from some ledger but like reading smoke signals against the sky. Looking for meaning behind meaning.

Back before all this there was only the Jews. Back when Rome first marched into Jerusalem like they owned it. Sixty-three years before the birth of Christ. The Jews weren't one people then neither. Sadducees. Pharisees. Essenes. Zealots. Common folk. All of them different as night and day but all reading from the same book. One God. One truth. One holy text. That's how it started.

There aint no mercy in the hearts of men. The Jungle shows us this truth plain as day and black as night. Deep in their cores men harbor only greed and self-preservation, a darkness that spreads like poison through their veins. They look not below them save to crush what lies beneath their boots.

You see it clearest in them factory owners and their kind. They build their empires on broken backs and spilled blood, caring nothing for the cost. Their ambitions rise like great black monoliths against the dying sky, and Sinclair writes of it thus: "The line of buildings stood clear-cut and black against the sky; here and there out of the mass rose the great chimneys, with the river of smoke streaming away to the end of the world." That smoke carries with it the dreams and lives of thousands, drifting off into nothingness while the masters count their coins.

These men care nothing for the destruction they wrought. Not for the poisoned earth nor the fouled waters running thick with offal from their killing floors. The air itself turned rank with the stench of progress, and still they pushed on, driven by that ancient hunger that knows no satisfaction.

Their workers was nothing more than cattle to them. Expendable. Replaceable. "A seething cauldron of jealousies and hatreds," Sinclair called it, where "no man counted for anything against a dollar."
