They'd work a man till his bones cracked then cast him aside like a spent shell casing, no more thought given than to the hogs they butchered.

Them that lived and died in Packingtown knew no salvation. No law protected them, no angel watched over their suffering. The unions that claimed to be their salvation was nothing but vultures picking at the same corpse. They was slaves in all but name, bound not by chains but by poverty and desperation. "Here is a population," the truth rings out, "low-class and mostly foreign, hanging always on the verge of starvation and dependent for its opportunities of life upon the whim of men every bit as brutal and unscrupulous as the old-time slave drivers." And so it was, and so it remains, the dark heart of man beating its terrible rhythm through the ages.

They say Dreamland was one of them poems Poe held dear above the others. Like a father with his favorite child. In it he wrote of Thulé, that word appearing twice like dark sentinels at the edges of his verse, and Mabbott in his wisdom traced it back to Virgil who spoke of some forsaken island past Britain where the known world gave way to darkness and myth. But there was something else. Something closer. The German scribes had caught Poe's eye and held it.

The truth of it lay in how Poe knew Goethe's work, deep and terrible. Arndt, in his scholarly wanderings through Poe's Politian and Goethe's Mignon, saw the ghost of one in the other, like a man recognizing his own reflection in muddy water.

Oxford tells us Goethe was a giant among men who birthed Faust into the world in two parts, the first in 1808 and the last in 1832 when death finally claimed him. Hidden in that second part was "The King of Thulé," a dark tale of a king whose queen passed leaving him naught but a goblet. He drank deep of his grief until the cup overflowed with tears and memory. When his time came he gave away all he owned save that cursed vessel. Walked to the edge of the world and cast it into the hungry sea before closing his eyes one final time. That king and the wraith in Dreamland might have been brothers, both shaped by loss and drink and darkness.

Grattan took Faust and made it his own in 1842, not a year before Poe wrote of Thule in "The Pit and the Pendulum." Like blood calling to blood. Twice Poe conjured Thule in his writings, once in Pendulum and twice more in Dreamland like bookends holding up worlds of shadow. Read them together, Goethe's King and Poe's Dreamland, and you'll see the same darkness reflected. The speaker walks through places where color goes to die, where ghosts of dead friends whisper on the wind, where loneliness has made its kingdom. Just as Goethe's king walked through his own private hell after his queen's passing.

Poe knew Goethe as sure as night knows day, if only through Tennyson whom he praised like a prophet. But there were other ways Goethe's words might have found him, carried on the winds of countless retellings after the master's death.

The law speaks of malice and rights and consequences but the truth of it lay deeper than any statute writ by men in their towers of concrete and steel. In the florescent-lit aisles of D&D Markets the applesauce spread like some viscous harbinger, a portent of what was to come while Martin sat in his office eating his dinner with the same methodical indifference that marked all his days.

They had told him twice. Wayne first and then Haddigan quarter hour later, their voices carrying the same warning through the stale store air but Martin had dismissed them both with words that hung like lead in the empty space between them. Didn't have time for customer complaints, he'd said, though time was all there was and all there ever would be.

When Palmer fell it was as if the world had been waiting for just such a moment. Her body twisted and broke against the hard tile floor like something preordained, her spine crackling with a sound like dry kindling. The fifth such falling that year, or perhaps the sixth, as if the store itself had developed a taste for broken bodies and spilled blood.

The question before the court was one of punishment beyond mere compensation, of whether Martin's disregard carried within it that special kind of darkness the law calls malice. The California code spoke of oppression and fraud and malice like ancient runes carved in legal stone, demanding proof of despicable conduct or willing disregard for the safety of others. And there was something in Martin's actions that spoke to this, something in the way he sat eating while knowing what lay in wait in his aisles, knowing what had come before and what would surely come again.

The judge would see it. In the cold fluorescent light of the courtroom he would recognize that special kind of darkness that lives in men who watch others suffer while they sup, who hear warnings and turn away, who know the consequences and choose them anyway. For this was not mere negligence but something older, something that spoke to the darkness that lives in all men's hearts.

The wanting lived in her like a hunger. Started when she was fourteen and hadnt left her yet. Three years gone and still it gnawed. Not a thing she needed now but someone and yet the boys who came calling stirred nothing in her heart. They made their clumsy advances like yearling colts testing weak legs but she turned from them all. She studied this emptiness like a crow picking through bones but found no answers there. Just the endless wanting and the questions that followed behind like pallbearers at a funeral that wouldnt end.

The house was quiet most days. Her parents moved through the rooms like ghosts barely disturbing the air. No shouting. No tears. When words did rise between them and their daughter they were about her wildness, her need to run free like some unbroken mare. She carried a fire in her that burned bright against their stillness but folk took to her anyway. Something in that flame drew them close despite the risk of burning.

Then came the day when quiet broke. A cry cut through the morning air sharp as a blade. Kitchen way. Her mothers voice twisted into something wrong. She ran calling out mama mama but the only answer was pain wrapped in short breaths. Found her mother laid out on the tile like something fallen from a great height. Touch gentle as prayer on her mothers shoulder. Take me to the hospital child the words coming broken and scattered like birds shot from the sky. She gathered her mother up blessed now for the strength in her arms. Carried her like something precious and fragile to the waiting car.

The hospital air was thick with death and antiseptic but she noticed none of it. Her world had narrowed to her mothers pain and the need to end it. Called out and white coats came running their faces masks of concern. They took her mother away on a wheeled bed and left her there in the waiting room with nothing but time and worry for company.

All this because a vase set too high needed reaching and a stepstool proved treacherous as any snake in the garden.

They sought truth in numbers and blood. The Mediterranean way of eating, ancient as the stones themselves, whispered promises of longer life through the statistics. Not in words but in the absence of dead hearts, in the flowing of clean blood through untainted vessels. They called it aMed, this scoring of meals, this counting of plants and fish and the oils that men had pressed from fruit since time before memory.

The old studies spoke their piece. Numbers carved into ledgers showing how men who ate from the earth's abundance, who shunned the heavy fats of beasts, lived longer. Their hearts beat stronger. But none had looked deep into the darkness of the stroke, that silent killer that steals mind and movement alike.

Seventy-four thousand eight hundred and eighty-six women they watched. Nurses all of them, scattered across eleven states like seeds in the wind. For twenty years they marked their eating in questionnaires, six times from 1984 to 2004, documenting each morsel as if writing their own salvation. They were faithful in their reporting, these women, more than ninety-five in every hundred staying true to the end.

The counters of numbers verified everything. When death came they searched through papers and certificates, autopsy reports telling tales of failed hearts and blocked vessels. Some they called probable, when the papers weren't there to tell the tale. Seventeen percent of strokes, twenty-four percent of heart failures, marked down in their ledgers like notches on a gun.

They tracked everything. Weight and smoke and pills. The movement of bodies in leisure and the changes that time brings to women's flesh. The numbers spoke of protection. Those who followed the old ways, eating as their ancestors did from the Mediterranean shores, they lived longer. Two thousand three hundred ninety-one hearts failed, one thousand seven hundred sixty-three minds darkened by stroke, one thousand seventy-seven souls claimed by the combined assault. But those who ate from the earth's bounty, they stood stronger. The numbers said so. Zero point seven one, they wrote in their books. A mathematical blessing, a ward against death.

Hitler lives, the sign said. Just that and nothing more upon the cardboard held aloft by the girl actor who'd once played pregnant in that picture show. She stood there in the gray morning like some soothsayer of old bearing portents and auguries.

They called it Burma though that wasnt its name no more. A land of temples and soldiers where men in ochre robes walked the streets in silence until they didnt. Until the streets ran red with their blood and the monasteries lay broken and burning in the perpetual dusk of that strange country. The government men had come up through ranks like carrion birds ascending, nineteen sixty two it was, and they ruled with iron and lead and all manner of cruelty that men devise when power fills their gullets.

In the year two thousand and seven the monks rose up. Saffron Revolution they called it though revolution it wasnt, just death dealt out like playing cards in some cosmic game where the house always wins. A Japanese man with a camera lay dying in the street while they watched. Thirteen dead said the papers but the colonel who fled knew different. Thousands, he said. Thousands.

These things aint new. Since men first gathered in tribes there been those who'd rule absolute. Roman emperors who claimed kinship with gods. Japanese kings who were gods themselves. Even now our own president takes counsel from prophets and madmen who speak in tongues of power and control.

The examples lay scattered through time like broken pottery. Tiananmen where tanks rolled over students who dared to dream. Rwanda where neighbor killed neighbor until the streets stank of death. Hitler's own Reich where the crematoriums burned day and night without ceasing. All of it written in blood on pages that history turns with indifferent hands.

The shadow of Duke Ellington looms long across the wasteland of jazz, not just in years but in the way he shaped and molded his orchestra like some dark craftsman at his forge. His piano work whispers through the compositions like wind through dead grass, but as architect of sound he built cathedrals of brass and wood where soloists could wander like prophets in the wilderness. He knew the voices of his men, knew them like a father knows his sons, and he wrote for their souls as much as their instruments. The framework he built was both prison and liberation, the tightly wound phrases and loose improvisations existing in the same space like light and dark at twilight.

The scholars speak of Creole Love Call as if speaking of ancient scripture, noting how he made the human voice into something otherworldly, stripped of words and meaning save what the soul could conjure. Six times the piece turns upon itself like a serpent consuming its tail. First comes the voice, pure as spring water then rough as desert stone, calling to the reeds that answer like lost children. Then the trumpet emerges from the darkness, muted and blue as midnight, followed by the clarinet that climbs toward heaven while the piano walks beneath it like a shadow. The full band rises up like a great beast, brass and reed speaking in tongues, until the fifth turning when everything reaches toward something unseen and terrible and beautiful. In the end the voice returns, growling like some creature that has forgotten it was once human, and the trombone speaks the final dissonant words like a priest delivering last rites.

A year later he conjured Hot and Bothered from the void, Miley's trumpet and Cox's voice speaking to each other like lovers in a dead language. And when It Don't Mean a Thing emerged from the darkness, Nanton's trombone spoke first, as if announcing the coming of something that could not be named. This was Ellington's way, to take the human and make it instrument, to take the brass and make it flesh, until you could no longer tell where one ended and the other began.

They come to us like questions in the dark. How the beasts of field and forest take their shapes and why. What forces bind them to their forms like prisoners to their chains. In 1917 Thompson wrote of how even the learned men of science had not yet begun to speak of living things in the tongue of numbers and equations and even now his words ring true across the wasteland of years.

The shells lie before us like calcified histories. Each one a testament to some ancient geometry that we cannot name. We study them, these remnants of Prunum, these spiral tombs of the creatures that once dwelt within. We gather their ghosts through machines that peer through their walls with invisible light and we feed these spectral measurements to newer machines that speak in electricity and silicon.

The shell is a prison built by its inmate, constructed in slow circles through time and space. Three hundred and sixty degrees of eternal return. The whorls spiral like a rope around nothing, around an axis that exists only in theory, in the mind. The columella stands sentinel at the center of it all. Each revolution grows according to some mathematical truth that we can only glimpse, like seeing shapes in smoke. The sutures mark time like notches on a prisoner's wall.

We arrange them in our taxonomies. Apical. Basal. Apertural. Abapertural. Words we use to impose order on chaos. We count the whorls like counting rings in a tree, measuring quarter turns as if such precision matters in the face of geological time. The aperture traces its path through space like a bullet through the dark, leaving behind only its calcified wake.

In the end we reduce it all to numbers. Coordinates. Trajectories. As if we could capture the essence of life in equations. As if we could understand the mind of God through mathematics. But the shells remain what they are. Silent witnesses to processes we can only pretend to comprehend.

The dead children of Indonesia lay like dark seeds in the earth, their numbers unchanging through the years, a grim testament carved in stone. The nation moved forward in some ways, meeting goals for water and clean places to shit, but the mothers and their young ones kept dying just the same, their blood seeping into soil that cared nothing for millennium goals or government promises.

They said more births now had someone who knew the old ways, seven of ten maybe, women who'd learned their craft from their mothers and grandmothers before them. But when the blood came, really came, these women stood helpless as the rest, watching life drain away in crimson rivers. Numbers on paper meant nothing to death. It took what it wanted.

In the cities they cut women open to save them, but not many. Four in hundred maybe. Out in the places where dirt roads turned to mud and electricity came and went like a fickle god, fewer still. The rich got their medicine and their doctors. The poor got their prayers. Twenty-seven percent difference between them, the bureaucrats said, as if poverty could be measured in clean decimals instead of dead children.

They argued about it in offices with air conditioning, whether to build special programs or fix the whole broken machine. Vertical approaches, they called them, like ladders to heaven. But every ladder they built seemed to steal from another, and the forms and papers multiplied like rats in a granary. Money flowed to AIDS while babies died of diarrhea, and the doctors chased the dollars like crows following a plow. Nothing changed except the numbers on the reports, and those numbers were written in blood.

The music they call Popular has grown wild and untamed these hundred years past, spreading like windblown seed across the land until no man could count its varieties. And these varieties bred new varieties and those bred still more until the names themselves became a babel of confusion. Rap and rock and country and jazz and folk, each spawning children darker and stranger than their fathers.

Among these bastard sons none grew more twisted and manifold than the thing they called Heavy Metal. It came slouching out of the darkness forty years ago and in its wake followed legions. Each new breed carrying some mark of its sire but warped and changed like creatures born in atomic fire. The darkness in it spoke to something in men's souls and they took it and shaped it to their own designs, each new shaping breeding yet more shapes until the very thing that spawned them all became impossible to name.

Now the metal walks among us in countless forms, like some demon that can wear any face it chooses. To understand this thing you must go back to where it began, back to the source of the darkness. For metal aint just music. It's a movement born in shadow and raised on blood and thunder.

They made it louder, heavier, more violent than what came before. The players were virtuosos of chaos, their instruments howling like the damned. And there were drugs, yes. In those mid-seventies years when the psychedelics flowed like water and men's minds turned to strange horizons. They made records that sound like dispatches from hell itself, blame it on the drugs if you want but the darkness was there already, waiting. The pretty music of those days couldn't speak to what was coming. But metal could. Metal did. Like some dark reflection of the Romantic composers of old, it reached into the shadows of men's souls and pulled forth something terrible and true.

In the years before the dreamers took to their canvases with their strange visions the man called Rousseau had already begun to paint his own. The dreams came to him like thieves in the night and he put them down with careful strokes as if marking the passage of something ancient and terrible. The Dream they called it. Nineteen hundred and ten. A woman lost in some savage paradise while beasts with eyes like burning coals watched from the darkness of the jungle. But the real dream was his own and it gnawed at him like hunger. Recognition. Acceptance. The approval of men who painted in ways he could not understand but desperately wished to join.

He was born to a tinsmith in Laval where the spring rains fell hard against the slate roofs and the streets ran with mud. No teacher ever showed him how to hold a brush or mix colors or capture the light that fell across the world like God's own thoughts. For forty years he collected tolls from travelers while the art lived inside him like some trapped animal trying to claw its way free. They called him douanier though that wasnt right. His first wife Clémence died and took eight babies with her to the cold ground leaving only Julia behind. The grief sat in him like lead and he turned to painting like a man turns to whiskey, hoping to drown something that cannot be drowned.

He worked in the shadow of giants. While Matisse and the others carved their names into history with wild colors and shapes that defied God's own design Rousseau labored in his simple way trying to make pictures that would please the men who decided such things. Matisse feared convention like it was a poison but Rousseau sought it like salvation. Two men walking different roads in the same dark wood. One running from what the other was running toward.

The folk painters heart beat in him true as any clock. He painted what he knew and what he dreamed and what he feared all at once and the pictures came out strange and wonderful though he never meant them to be. His dreams of acceptance lay in him like stones but the pictures that came from his hands were something else entirely. Something wild. Something true.

They say truth and beauty walk together like old companions on a dusty road. Been that way since before any living soul drew breath. Keats knew it when he wrote them words about the urn, beauty being truth and truth being all we need know in this world. Most things a man learns come from books or hard living but the knowing of right and wrong, the seeing of what's beautiful, that comes from somewhere deeper. Like an old well that ain't got no bottom.

You can study it all you want. Write down rules about what makes something right or pretty. But they're just words on paper, trying to catch smoke in your hands. Take that painting, the Mona Lisa. Folk talk about shadow and light, about what was happening in Italy back then, but that ain't really it. When someone loves a thing, really loves it, first words out their mouth is always something like "there's just something about it." Rest comes after, like trying to explain why you love your momma.

O'Connor, she knew. Said some things can only be told in stories because regular talk won't do. Like trying to describe the taste of water to someone who ain't never drunk none. Same goes for knowing right from wrong. Wittgenstein said ethics can't be spoke of proper, and he wasn't wrong. There's something in both art and right living that sits beyond words, like a far-off mountain you can see but never reach.

Way I figure it, that's why stories and morals run so close together, like two streams joining in the valley. They both hit us somewhere deep, somewhere we can feel but can't point to. Literature especially. McKean had it right when he said books carry moral weight same as life does. Can't live without choosing between right and wrong, and can't tell stories without doing the same. That's what makes them matter. That's what makes them true.

The Germany that stands now rises like a sentinel, unified and stark against the heavens, its essence flowing from the shadow-kept valleys of München where the alps loom black and ancient to the cold waters of Kiel where the Baltic meets the shore in eternal conflict. This essence, this blood-memory, courses through the veins of cities from Köln where the Rhine cuts deep and merciless, through the heartland to Dresden where the Elbe winds like a steel serpent through Saxon stone. And in this land where darkness and light wage their endless war, the roots run deep into soil watered by the blood of tribes long forgotten.

Germania. The word itself carries weight like old bones in the earth. Men argue its meaning like crows fighting over carrion, each pecking at truth with black beaks. Tacitus, that Roman who peered into the darkness beyond the empire's reach, spoke of the Tungrians who crossed the Rhine with fire and steel, becoming Germans in the crossing. Caesar too marked them in his writings, ink flowing like blood across parchment as he recorded their raids, their savage dance across borders that meant nothing to them. The word itself perhaps meant neighbor in the tongue of the Gauls, or maybe it spoke of the spear they carried, the ger, death-dealer in the hands of warriors. Or perhaps it rose from garim, a scream in the Old Irish night, for these were a people who made the darkness echo with their war-cries.

Tacitus wrote of them as if writing of wolves or winter storms, creatures born of the land itself. Not mixed with others, he said, for who would choose such wilderness, such brutal skies, such a land that wore its hostility like a crown? The Germans were aboriginal, sprung from soil and ice and darkness.

The Romans came and went like summer storms, taking what they could carry, leading their legions into the depths of Germania only to retreat again to their marble cities and heated baths. And the Germans remained, trading with the empire that feared them, serving in its armies while keeping their own savage hearts. They dwelt in the borderlands like shadows at the edge of firelight, taking what they needed from the land and from Rome itself, patient as winter, eternal as the forests that bore them.

In the dark heart of Twelfth Night there dwells a truth about masks and the wearing of them, how they serve their purpose like a knife serves its wielder but in time will turn against the flesh that holds them. The shedding of such guises becomes necessary lest the wearer lose themselves to the void that lies between what is and what seems to be. But there aint no easy way to cast off what's become a second skin and them that's been deceived may turn cold as winter stone or hot as desert fury when the truth comes calling.

The matter of gender masquerade carries its own peculiar burden, like a snake that eats its own tail, forever asking why. Why does the soul seek to shed its given form and take up another? Viola speaks plain enough about it: "I'll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count..." The words hang in the air like smoke from a dying fire.

She come to these foreign shores alone and afraid and took up man's clothing like armor against the world's malice. But such protection carries its own poison. It sets her apart from her own kind, leaves her to walk alone among women who might have been sisters to her. And Olivia, God help her, sees in Viola's disguise what she wants to see, calling out "Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay." The words fall like dead birds from her lips. And there's Orsino too, speaking words that cut like broken glass: "Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me."

Maybe them that read these words now might see something deeper, like looking into a well at midnight. Maybe they'd say this tale shows how lies can sometimes midwife truth into the world, especially in Olivia and Orsino's case. Their desires lay buried like bones in the desert until Viola's deception dug them up. Some might wonder if Olivia's heart truly yearned for women all along, but that aint likely what Shakespeare meant. More like he was mocking them that judge love by its container rather than its contents.

You can see it clear as day when Olivia turns her affections from Cesario to Sebastian quick as a rattler strikes, and speaks to Viola like blood kin: "A sister, you are she." The words ring true at last, like a bell in the darkness that finally finds its proper tone.

They spoke of the German rule in whispers. Of cruelties visited upon the Ovaherero and the Nama peoples in that sunscorched land they called South West Africa. But empires aint built on simple tales and the Germans ruled different lands different ways and some flourished while others withered beneath the weight of their governance.

In the east where the British come to rule in 1919 they found natives who could read and write and cipher numbers like educated men. Same in Kamerun where even the white men spoke well of what the Germans had done. But South West Africa was different. Something darker there.

The missionaries come with their books and their crosses but the government gave them nothing. No help. No coin. While the white children got their schools built fine with government money and the mission schools for whites got what they needed too. These things cast long shadows and while other colonies had natives who could read and write and make their way in the white man's world South West Africa remained in darkness. Its people untouched. Unlearned. Unable to read the very papers that marked their fate.

Men wrote about these things. German men mostly, in the early days of the century, putting down in their own tongue what they saw in these far places. Later others come. English speakers who looked at how different colonies fared different fates. Cohen was one. He wrote about the schools in South West Africa and East Africa both, trying to make sense of why one flourished while the other failed. He said it was the settlers that made the difference. Too many whites in South West Africa wanting to keep things their way.

The land there wasnt like the other colonies. Not so hot. Not so wet. Desert mostly but liveable if you were white and determined. By 1913 fifteen thousand whites had made it their home while East Africa, the next most settled place, had barely five thousand. They come for the temperate air and the promise of mastery over the land and its people. And master it they did.

They rode forth across that contested earth, these two nations, like ancient enemies bound by blood and soil. From 1836 to 1893 they circled each other like wounded wolves, fifty-seven years of malice carved into the very ground beneath them. The war came in 1846, as wars do, and the American forces descended upon Mexico like locusts, stripping away Texas and the Southwest territories, leaving behind nothing but dust and memory.

The border between them was a wound that would not heal. Like all neighbors cursed by proximity they found in each other a mirror of their own fears, their own hatreds. Their differences ran deep as burial grounds - God and custom and the old ways setting them apart like oil and water in a jar. Cuba too stood watching from across the water, another thorn in the American flesh, while the rest of Latin America kept its distance, wise perhaps in its caution.

Religion lay between them like a rusted blade. The Protestant Americans carried their prejudices from the old world, wearing their distrust of Catholics like armor, just as their English forebears had done. The Spanish shadow fell long across Mexico, and in its darkness old hatred grew like weeds in untended fields.

Seventeen times they clashed in those bitter years, mostly over the border that cut through the land like a scar. Bandits and murderers moved across it like ghosts, striking at towns on both sides, until finally both nations sent their armies to stand watch over that invisible line. The rivalry died slow, like all ancient things must die, when Mexico fell into the economic embrace of its northern neighbor, American ambition turning from land to money, as it always does in the end.

The old ways changed. The old blood dried. But the memory remained, etched into the stones and the sand and the bones of all those who died in that time when two nations stared across a line drawn in dust, each seeing in the other a darkness they feared in themselves.

Fifteen years back the sickness came. Not gradual like winter but sudden and complete, a thing I'd never heard tell of before it took me.

I was a nurse then. Chose it out of some hollow need for safety, the kind that gets bred into you when you're young and afraid. They'd say you'll always find work cause folks'll always be dying or trying not to. So I buried deeper things, dreams of science and truth-telling, and took up with the sick and dying instead.

There I was at forty-six. Alone. No money to speak of and work become impossible as breath to a hanged man. Fifteen years living on government alms and now nothing remains that's truly mine. Each day comes like a thief in the night, stealing what little security remains. Nothing certain anymore except this one truth: that without my blood kin and the few true friends, I'd have been gone to dust. When the real darkness comes it strips you bare of all pretense of strength.

Life's got its catastrophes waiting, big and small like wolves in the night. No matter how you prepare some storms are too big to weather alone. Ain't no guarantee written in stone or sky.

The government's basket's got holes and the bottom's falling out, sure as sunrise. But better we learn to trust each other again than each man digging his own grave in the backyard calling it shelter. They talk about rugged individualism like it built this nation, but that ain't the truth of it. What kept our ancestors breathing was mercy and respect and the sharing of what little they had. Them wagon trains didn't cross the mountains one by one.

So lay in your stores. Keep your matches dry and your water clean. Stack your canned goods like gold bars if you want. Plant your garden if the earth'll have you. But while you're doing all that surviving, remember your neighbor's light in the window. Might be the only thing between you and the dark when it comes.

He was born a prince in the old world, in times when men still believed the earth was flat and the heavens hung low like a tapestry of black velvet studded with cold fire. They would later call him Buddha. The years counted backward twenty five hundred times since then, since he walked away from wealth and crown to seek what lay beyond the veil of human suffering. What he found became Buddhism and the Theravada followed, pure as mountain water, orthodox as stone.

The thing that was then aint the thing that is now. In Sri Lanka they cut water once each year, monks and common folk gathered like dark birds at the edge of sacred pools, performing rituals the Buddha never spoke of. Time changes all things. Even truth. Even doctrine. The Theravada Buddhist folk, them that wear robes and them that dont, have watched their beliefs shift like sand in desert winds, pushed by forces within and without, some meaning harm and others meaning nothing at all but bringing change regardless.

Words matter here. Internal is what comes from inside the Buddhasasana, be it monk or layman that brings it. External is all else, the outsider, the stranger, the other. Some forces come with teeth bared and claws extended, seeking to tear down what Buddha built. These are hostile. Others come blank-faced and indifferent, neither meaning good nor ill, though they may bring either. These are benign. Remember these words. They'll come again.

The heart of it all beats steady beneath. Three jewels they seek refuge in: Buddha, Dhamma, Sangha. The Dhamma lives in three baskets of ancient words. Suttas telling tales and teachings. Vinaya speaking law. Abhidhamma reaching into the spaces between spaces where metaphysics dwell. They speak of Anatta, the great emptiness where soul should be. Of Dukkha, the suffering that runs through all things like dark threads through pale cloth. Of Anicca, how nothing lasts, nothing stays, nothing holds. Know these and you might break free of Sansara, that wheel that turns and turns, grinding life into death into life again. Break free of want and hate and the fog that clouds mens minds. The Vinaya tells how to live. Five rules for common folk: kill not, lie not, steal not, keep your loins in check, stay clear of drink and drugs that cloud the mind. Monks got more rules. Many more. But at the center of it all stand four truths like stone pillars holding up the sky. Life is suffering. Want brings suffering. Suffering can end.
